1# Spec: Anthropic OAuth Gateway
     2
     3**Status:** Complete
     4**Created:** 2026-02-09
     5**Author:** Brent + Cowork
     6**Supersedes:** `oauth-proxy.md` (header injector  full OAuth gateway)
     7
     8---
     9
    10## Overview
    11
    12Evolve the anthropic-oauth-proxy from a static header injector into a full OAuth 2.0 gateway with subscription pooling. The proxy currently passes through client-provided `Authorization` headers and injects `anthropic-beta: oauth-2025-04-20`. The target state manages its own OAuth credentials: PKCE authentication flow, automatic token refresh, round-robin subscription pooling with quota failover, and the full Anthropic header contract.
    13
    14Clients on the tailnet send unauthenticated requests. The gateway handles everything.
    15
    16**Pins:**
    17
    18| Reference | What it provides |
    19|-----------|-----------------|
    20| Loom `specs/claude-subscription-auth.md` | OAuth 2.0 PKCE flow, token exchange/refresh, credential storage, header contract |
    21| Loom `specs/anthropic-oauth-pool.md` | Subscription pooling, round-robin failover, quota detection, health reporting |
    22| Loom `specs/anthropic-max-pool-management.md` | Admin API patterns, proactive token refresh, account lifecycle |
    23| Aperture by Tailscale | Multi-provider gateway architecture, Tailscale identity, model-based routing |
    24
    25**Design Principles (carried forward):**
    26
    27| Principle | Implementation |
    28|-----------|----------------|
    29| Single responsibility | One binary, one provider (Anthropic) |
    30| Provider trait | Multi-provider interface designed in, only Anthropic implemented |
    31| Tailnet-native | MagicDNS identity via Tailscale Operator |
    32| Pure state machines | Auth state, pool state, service lifecycle  all explicit |
    33| Zero client credentials | Clients send bare requests; gateway injects everything |
    34
    35---
    36
    37## Architecture
    38
    39```text
    40
    41                              Tailnet                                      
    42                                                                           
    43              
    44   Aperture   Tailscale     anthropic-oauth-proxy         
    45   (http://ai/)     Operator                                         
    46         Ingress                
    47                               OAuth Pool             
    48                                         
    49  ForgeFlare     Max1   Max2 ...     
    50                                                  
    51                                                     
    52                                  
    53   Claude                                  
    54   Code                                                              
    55                                  
    56                                            Header Injection          
    57                                            + System Prompt Gate      
    58                                            + Token Refresh           
    59                                              
    60                                          
    61                                                                         
    62                                                                         
    63                                              api.anthropic.com           
    64
    65```
    66
    67MagicDNS hostname remains `anthropic-oauth-proxy`. Same Tailscale Ingress, same K8s footprint. Binary name unchanged. The upgrade is internal.
    68
    69---
    70
    71## Auth Modes
    72
    73The gateway supports two mutually exclusive auth modes, determined at startup:
    74
    75| Mode | Source | Behavior |
    76|------|--------|----------|
    77| **Passthrough** (current) | `[headers]` config with no `[oauth]` section | Inject static headers, pass through client Authorization. Backward compatible. |
    78| **OAuth Pool** | `[oauth]` section present | Manage credentials, inject Bearer token + full header contract. Client Authorization ignored. |
    79
    80This preserves backward compatibility. Existing deployments with `[[headers]]` config continue to work. Adding an `[oauth]` section activates the new behavior.
    81
    82---
    83
    84## Multi-Provider Interface
    85
    86The gateway is Anthropic-only but the provider abstraction is designed for future extension.
    87
    88### Provider Trait
    89
    90```rust
    91/// Trait for LLM provider authentication and request preparation.
    92/// Anthropic is the only implementation. Designed for future providers
    93/// (OpenAI, Google) without breaking changes.
    94pub trait Provider: Send + Sync {
    95    /// Provider identifier (e.g., "anthropic")
    96    fn id(&self) -> &str;
    97
    98    /// Prepare an outbound request: inject auth headers, modify body if needed.
    99    /// Called once per proxy attempt (not per retry).
   100    async fn prepare_request(
   101        &self,
   102        request: &mut RequestBuilder,
   103        body: &mut serde_json::Value,
   104    ) -> Result<(), ProviderError>;
   105
   106    /// Classify an upstream error for failover decisions.
   107    fn classify_error(&self, status: u16, body: &str) -> ErrorClassification;
   108
   109    /// Report an error back to the provider (e.g., mark account as cooling).
   110    async fn report_error(
   111        &self,
   112        classification: ErrorClassification,
   113    ) -> Result<(), ProviderError>;
   114
   115    /// Health status for the /health endpoint.
   116    async fn health(&self) -> ProviderHealth;
   117}
   118```
   119
   120### Error Classification
   121
   122```rust
   123#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy)]
   124pub enum ErrorClassification {
   125    /// Transient error, retry on same account (via existing retry loop)
   126    Transient,
   127    /// Quota exhausted, failover to next account in pool
   128    QuotaExceeded,
   129    /// Permanent error (bad credentials), disable account
   130    Permanent,
   131}
   132```
   133
   134---
   135
   136## OAuth Implementation
   137
   138### Constants
   139
   140```rust
   141/// Anthropic's public OAuth client ID (same as Claude CLI)
   142pub const ANTHROPIC_CLIENT_ID: &str = "9d1c250a-e61b-44d9-88ed-5944d1962f5e";
   143
   144/// OAuth redirect URI
   145pub const REDIRECT_URI: &str = "https://console.anthropic.com/oauth/code/callback";
   146
   147/// Token endpoint
   148pub const TOKEN_ENDPOINT: &str = "https://console.anthropic.com/v1/oauth/token";
   149
   150/// Authorization endpoint (Pro/Max subscriptions)
   151pub const AUTHORIZE_ENDPOINT: &str = "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize";
   152
   153/// OAuth scopes (user:sessions:claude_code required for Sonnet/Opus)
   154/// Note: org:create_api_key is NOT included  that's for Console OAuth (API key creation),
   155/// which is out of scope. This gateway only does Max (claude.ai) authorization.
   156pub const SCOPES: &str = "user:profile user:inference user:sessions:claude_code";
   157
   158/// Required system prompt prefix for Opus/Sonnet access
   159pub const REQUIRED_SYSTEM_PROMPT_PREFIX: &str =
   160    "You are Claude Code, Anthropic's official CLI for Claude.";
   161```
   162
   163### PKCE Flow
   164
   165Standard OAuth 2.0 with PKCE (RFC 7636). No client secret (public client).
   166
   167```text
   168Admin CLI                    Gateway                     claude.ai
   169                                                           
   170      add-account                                          
   171                                
   172                                 Generate PKCE pair        
   173                                 (verifier + S256 challenge)
   174      authorization_url                                    
   175                                
   176                                                           
   177      Open browser 
   178                                                           
   179      User authorizes                                      
   180    
   181                                                           
   182      Paste code#{state}                                   
   183                                
   184                                 POST /v1/oauth/token      
   185                               
   186                                 {access, refresh, expires}
   187                               
   188                                                           
   189                                 Store credentials         
   190                                 Add to pool (hot-reload)  
   191      Account added                                        
   192                                
   193```
   194
   195### Credential Storage
   196
   197JSON file on disk, keyed by account ID. Mounted as a PersistentVolume in K8s.
   198
   199```json
   200{
   201  "claude-max-1": {
   202    "type": "oauth",
   203    "refresh": "rt_abc123...",
   204    "access": "at_xyz789...",
   205    "expires": 1735500000000
   206  },
   207  "claude-max-2": {
   208    "type": "oauth",
   209    "refresh": "rt_def456...",
   210    "access": "at_uvw000...",
   211    "expires": 1735500100000
   212  }
   213}
   214```
   215
   216File permissions: `0600`, owned by container UID 1000 (non-root). Never exposed via API. Health endpoint shows account IDs and status only.
   217
   218**Atomic writes:** Credential file updates use write-to-temp + atomic rename to prevent corruption on crash mid-write. All writes acquire an in-memory `Mutex` to prevent concurrent modification from request-time refresh and background refresh tasks.
   219
   220**Cold start:** If credential file does not exist, create it as `{}`. Pool starts with zero accounts, health reports `unhealthy` with `accounts_total: 0`. First request returns 503 until an account is added via admin API.
   221
   222---
   223
   224## Subscription Pool
   225
   226### Account State Machine
   227
   228```rust
   229#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq)]
   230pub enum AccountStatus {
   231    /// Ready to serve requests
   232    Available,
   233    /// Hit 5-hour quota, cooling down
   234    CoolingDown { until: Instant },
   235    /// Permanently failed (invalid credentials, revoked token)
   236    Disabled,
   237}
   238```
   239
   240### State Transitions
   241
   242| Current | Trigger | New State | Action |
   243|---------|---------|-----------|--------|
   244| `Available` | Request succeeds | `Available` | None |
   245| `Available` | 429 + quota message | `CoolingDown` | Log, failover to next |
   246| `Available` | 401/403 | `Disabled` | Log error, failover |
   247| `Available` | Transient error | `Available` | Retry (existing retry loop) |
   248| `CoolingDown` | Cooldown expired | `Available` | Log recovery |
   249| `CoolingDown` | Token refresh fails | `Disabled` | Log error |
   250| `Disabled` | Admin removes | (removed) | Persist credential file |
   251
   252State transitions apply uniformly: a 401/403 from token refresh (request-time or background) transitions the account to `Disabled` regardless of previous state. `CoolingDown` accounts that fail background refresh go directly to `Disabled`.
   253
   254### Account Selection (Round-Robin)
   255
   2561. Start from `next_index`
   2572. Scan N accounts for `Available` status
   2583. Check `CoolingDown` accounts  if cooldown expired, transition to `Available`
   2594. Select first `Available`, advance `next_index`
   2605. If none available  503 Service Unavailable:
   261```json
   262{
   263  "error": {
   264    "type": "pool_exhausted",
   265    "message": "All accounts exhausted",
   266    "pool": {
   267      "accounts_total": 2,
   268      "accounts_available": 0,
   269      "accounts_cooling": 2,
   270      "accounts_disabled": 0
   271    }
   272  }
   273}
   274```
   275
   276### Quota Detection
   277
   278Not all 429s are quota exhaustion. The classifier inspects the error message body:
   279
   280| HTTP Status | Message Pattern | Classification |
   281|-------------|----------------|----------------|
   282| 429 | Contains "5-hour", "5 hour", "rolling window", "usage limit for your plan", "subscription usage limit" | `QuotaExceeded` |
   283| 429 | Other rate limit messages | `Transient` |
   284| 401, 403 | Any | `Permanent` |
   285| 408, 500, 502, 503, 504 | Any | `Transient` |
   286
   287### Cooldown
   288
   289Default: 2 hours (configurable via `cooldown_secs`). Conservative  the actual 5-hour window is rolling, so 2h is a safe recovery margin.
   290
   291---
   292
   293## Request Pipeline
   294
   295The gateway modifies both headers and body before forwarding.
   296
   297### Header Injection (OAuth Mode)
   298
   299| Header | Value | Notes |
   300|--------|-------|-------|
   301| `Authorization` | `Bearer {access_token}` | From selected pool account. Client-provided Authorization is **ignored** (stripped before injection). |
   302| `anthropic-beta` | `oauth-2025-04-20,interleaved-thinking-2025-05-14,context-management-2025-06-27` | Must include `oauth-2025-04-20` |
   303| `anthropic-dangerous-direct-browser-access` | `true` | Required for OAuth |
   304| `user-agent` | `claude-cli/2.0.76 (external, sdk-cli)` | Must match Claude CLI format |
   305| `anthropic-version` | `2023-06-01` | API version |
   306
   307Client-provided `anthropic-beta` values are merged (deduplicated) with the required set.
   308
   309### System Prompt Prefix Injection
   310
   311For Opus and Sonnet models, the system prompt **must** start with the exact phrase:
   312
   313```text
   314You are Claude Code, Anthropic's official CLI for Claude.
   315```
   316
   317The gateway inspects the request body:
   318
   319| Condition | Action |
   320|-----------|--------|
   321| No `system` field | Inject `system` with required prefix |
   322| `system` field exists, missing prefix | Prepend prefix + `" "` + existing content |
   323| `system` field exists, has prefix | No modification |
   324| Model is Haiku | No modification (prefix not required) |
   325
   326```rust
   327fn inject_system_prompt(body: &mut serde_json::Value, model: &str) {
   328    // Haiku doesn't need the prefix
   329    if model.contains("haiku") {
   330        return;
   331    }
   332
   333    let prefix = REQUIRED_SYSTEM_PROMPT_PREFIX;
   334
   335    match body.get_mut("system") {
   336        None => {
   337            body["system"] = serde_json::Value::String(prefix.to_string());
   338        }
   339        Some(system) => {
   340            if let Some(s) = system.as_str() {
   341                if !s.starts_with(prefix) {
   342                    *system = serde_json::Value::String(
   343                        format!("{} {}", prefix, s)
   344                    );
   345                }
   346            }
   347        }
   348    }
   349}
   350```
   351
   352### Model Extraction
   353
   354The gateway extracts the model name from the request body to determine:
   355
   3561. Whether system prompt injection is needed (non-Haiku)
   3572. Logging and metrics labels
   358
   359```rust
   360fn extract_model(body: &serde_json::Value) -> Option<&str> {
   361    body.get("model").and_then(|v| v.as_str())
   362}
   363```
   364
   365### Body Handling Path
   366
   367The current proxy forwards request bodies as opaque bytes. OAuth mode requires body modification (system prompt injection), which means `bytes  serde_json::Value  modify  serialize  forward`. This is the riskiest refactor  it touches the hot path and introduces a JSON round-trip that could alter field ordering, whitespace, or unicode escapes.
   368
   369| Mode | Body Path | Cost |
   370|------|-----------|------|
   371| Passthrough | Opaque bytes forwarded unchanged | Zero overhead (existing behavior) |
   372| OAuth | Deserialize  modify  serialize | JSON round-trip on every request |
   373
   374Design choice: **always deserialize in OAuth mode.** The latency of an Anthropic API call (seconds) dwarfs JSON serde time (microseconds). Optimizing with string-scan peeking adds complexity for negligible gain at this scale.
   375
   376The `Provider` trait receives `&mut serde_json::Value` so providers that don't need body modification (future OpenAI provider) can simply no-op. The deserialization happens once in `proxy.rs` before calling `provider.prepare_request()`, only when the provider is in OAuth mode.
   377
   378---
   379
   380## Token Refresh
   381
   382### Auto-Refresh on Request
   383
   384Before each proxied request, the gateway checks the selected account's token expiration:
   385
   386| Condition | Action |
   387|-----------|--------|
   388| Token valid (>60s remaining) | Use current access token |
   389| Token expiring (<60s) or expired | Refresh via `POST /v1/oauth/token` with `grant_type=refresh_token` |
   390| Refresh succeeds | Update in-memory + persist to credential file |
   391| Refresh fails | Mark account `Disabled`, failover to next |
   392
   393### Proactive Background Refresh
   394
   395A background tokio task runs independently of request flow:
   396
   397| Parameter | Default | Config Key |
   398|-----------|---------|------------|
   399| Check interval | 5 minutes | `refresh_interval_secs` |
   400| Refresh threshold | 15 minutes | `refresh_threshold_secs` |
   401
   402The task iterates all accounts, refreshing any token expiring within the threshold. This prevents mid-request refresh latency under normal operation.
   403
   404---
   405
   406## Configuration
   407
   408### File Format (TOML)
   409
   410```toml
   411# anthropic-oauth-proxy.toml
   412
   413[proxy]
   414listen_addr = "0.0.0.0:8080"
   415upstream_url = "https://api.anthropic.com"
   416timeout_secs = 60
   417max_connections = 1000
   418
   419# OAuth pool configuration (presence activates OAuth mode)
   420[oauth]
   421credential_file = "/data/credentials.json"
   422cooldown_secs = 7200          # 2 hours
   423refresh_interval_secs = 300   # 5 minutes
   424refresh_threshold_secs = 900  # 15 minutes
   425
   426# Static accounts to load from credential file at startup
   427# New accounts can be added at runtime via admin API
   428providers = ["claude-max-1", "claude-max-2"]
   429
   430# Admin API (for account management)
   431[admin]
   432enabled = true
   433listen_addr = "0.0.0.0:9090"  # Separate port, not exposed via Ingress
   434```
   435
   436When `[oauth]` is absent, the gateway falls back to passthrough mode using `[[headers]]` (backward compatible with current config). If both `[oauth]` and `[[headers]]` are present, `[oauth]` takes precedence and `[[headers]]` is ignored.
   437
   438### Environment Variables
   439
   440| Variable | Description |
   441|----------|-------------|
   442| `CONFIG_PATH` | Config file path (existing) |
   443| `LOG_LEVEL` | Logging verbosity (existing) |
   444| `CREDENTIAL_FILE` | Override credential file path |
   445
   446---
   447
   448## Admin API
   449
   450Separate listener on a non-Ingress port. Accessed via `kubectl port-forward` (authenticated by Kubernetes kubeconfig). Not exposed to the tailnet.
   451
   452**Single-pod requirement:** PKCE state is in-memory. The gateway runs as a single-replica Deployment. Multi-pod is not supported for the admin API flow (init-oauth on pod A, complete-oauth on pod B would fail). This is acceptable  account management is a rare admin operation, not a hot path.
   453
   454### Endpoints
   455
   456| Method | Path | Description |
   457|--------|------|-------------|
   458| `GET` | `/admin/accounts` | List accounts with status |
   459| `POST` | `/admin/accounts/init-oauth` | Start OAuth PKCE flow, returns authorization URL |
   460| `POST` | `/admin/accounts/complete-oauth` | Complete OAuth flow with authorization code |
   461| `DELETE` | `/admin/accounts/{id}` | Remove account from pool |
   462| `GET` | `/admin/pool` | Pool status summary |
   463
   464### Account ID Generation
   465
   466New accounts are assigned IDs in the format `claude-max-{unix_timestamp}` (e.g., `claude-max-1739059200`). Must be unique within the credential file.
   467
   468### PKCE State Storage
   469
   470Between `init-oauth` and `complete-oauth`, the gateway stores PKCE verifiers in an in-memory `HashMap<String, PkceState>` keyed by account ID. Entries expire after 10 minutes. No persistence needed  if the gateway restarts mid-flow, the admin simply re-initiates.
   471
   472```rust
   473struct PkceState {
   474    verifier: String,
   475    created_at: Instant,
   476}
   477```
   478
   479### Init OAuth Response
   480
   481```json
   482{
   483  "authorization_url": "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize?client_id=...&code_challenge=...&state=...",
   484  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
   485  "instructions": "Open the URL in a browser, authorize, then paste the code to complete-oauth"
   486}
   487```
   488
   489### Complete OAuth Request
   490
   491```json
   492{
   493  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
   494  "code": "{authorization_code}#{state}"
   495}
   496```
   497
   498---
   499
   500## Health Endpoint (Upgraded)
   501
   502The existing `/health` endpoint expands to include pool status:
   503
   504### Passthrough Mode (backward compatible)
   505
   506```json
   507{
   508  "status": "healthy",
   509  "mode": "passthrough",
   510  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   511  "requests_served": 12345,
   512  "errors_total": 0
   513}
   514```
   515
   516### OAuth Pool Mode
   517
   518```json
   519{
   520  "status": "healthy",
   521  "mode": "oauth_pool",
   522  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   523  "requests_served": 12345,
   524  "errors_total": 0,
   525  "pool": {
   526    "accounts_total": 3,
   527    "accounts_available": 2,
   528    "accounts_cooling": 1,
   529    "accounts_disabled": 0,
   530    "accounts": [
   531      { "id": "claude-max-1", "status": "available" },
   532      { "id": "claude-max-2", "status": "cooling_down", "cooldown_remaining_secs": 3600 },
   533      { "id": "claude-max-3", "status": "available" }
   534    ]
   535  }
   536}
   537```
   538
   539### Health Status Mapping
   540
   541| Pool State | Status |
   542|------------|--------|
   543| All available | `healthy` |
   544| 1 available, some cooling/disabled | `degraded` |
   545| All cooling or disabled | `unhealthy` (still returns 200  Kubernetes probes check JSON) |
   546
   547---
   548
   549## Metrics (Extended)
   550
   551Existing metrics are preserved. New metrics for OAuth:
   552
   553| Metric | Type | Labels |
   554|--------|------|--------|
   555| `proxy_requests_total` | Counter | `status`, `method` (existing) |
   556| `proxy_request_duration_seconds` | Histogram | `status` (existing) |
   557| `proxy_upstream_errors_total` | Counter | `error_type` (existing) |
   558| `pool_account_status` | Gauge | `account_id`, `status` |
   559| `pool_failovers_total` | Counter | `from_account`, `reason` |
   560| `pool_token_refreshes_total` | Counter | `account_id`, `result` |
   561| `pool_quota_exhaustions_total` | Counter | `account_id` |
   562
   563---
   564
   565## Project Structure (Target)
   566
   567```text
   568crates/
   569  common/               # Shared types: error types (existing)
   570  provider/             # NEW: Provider trait, ErrorClassification
   571  anthropic-auth/       # NEW: OAuth PKCE, token refresh, credential storage
   572  anthropic-pool/       # NEW: Subscription pool, round-robin, failover
   573services/
   574  oauth-proxy/          # Existing binary, upgraded
   575    src/
   576      main.rs           # Entry point (existing, extended)
   577      config.rs         # Config (existing, extended with [oauth] section)
   578      service.rs        # Service state machine (existing)
   579      proxy.rs          # HTTP proxy (existing, call provider.prepare_request())
   580      metrics.rs        # Metrics (existing, extended)
   581      admin.rs          # NEW: Admin API routes
   582      provider_impl.rs  # NEW: AnthropicProvider implementing Provider trait
   583specs/
   584  oauth-proxy.md              # Original spec (Complete, preserved)
   585  anthropic-oauth-gateway.md  # This spec
   586```
   587
   588### Crate Dependency Graph
   589
   590```text
   591oauth-proxy (binary)
   592   common
   593   provider          (trait definition)
   594   anthropic-auth    (PKCE, token refresh, credentials)
   595   anthropic-pool    (pool state, selection, failover)
   596         anthropic-auth
   597```
   598
   599---
   600
   601## Deployment Changes
   602
   603### PersistentVolumeClaim
   604
   605Credential file must survive pod restarts. Add a PVC mounted at `/data/`:
   606
   607```yaml
   608apiVersion: v1
   609kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
   610metadata:
   611  name: anthropic-oauth-credentials
   612  namespace: tailnet
   613spec:
   614  accessModes: [ReadWriteOnce]
   615  resources:
   616    requests:
   617      storage: 1Mi
   618```
   619
   620### ConfigMap Update
   621
   622Add `[oauth]` section to the existing ConfigMap. Backward compatible  removing the section reverts to passthrough mode.
   623
   624### Service (Admin)
   625
   626Optional second Service on port 9090 for admin API. Not exposed via Ingress. Accessible via `kubectl port-forward` or from within the cluster.
   627
   628### No Other Changes
   629
   630Same Deployment, same Ingress, same MagicDNS hostname, same container image tag pattern. The binary detects its mode from config.
   631
   632---
   633
   634## Implementation Phases
   635
   636### Phase 1: Provider Abstraction + Mode Detection
   637
   638- [x] Create `crates/provider/` with `Provider` trait and `ErrorClassification`
   639- [x] Create `PassthroughProvider` implementing `Provider` trait (wraps current header injection logic)
   640- [x] Extend `config.rs` with `[oauth]` section parsing and mode detection
   641- [x] Refactor `proxy.rs` to call `provider.prepare_request()` instead of inline header injection
   642- [x] Body handling fork: passthrough = opaque bytes, oauth = deserialize (stubbed  passthrough provider uses opaque path)
   643- [x] All existing tests pass, behavior unchanged (passthrough provider reproduces current behavior exactly)
   644
   645### Phase 2: OAuth Foundation
   646
   647- [x] Create `crates/anthropic-auth/` with PKCE generation (verifier + S256 challenge)
   648- [x] Implement token exchange (`authorization_code` grant)
   649- [x] Implement token refresh (`refresh_token` grant)
   650- [x] Implement credential file storage (read/write JSON, 0600 permissions)
   651- [x] Unit tests for PKCE, exchange, refresh, storage
   652
   653### Phase 3: Subscription Pool
   654
   655- [x] Create `crates/anthropic-pool/` with `AccountStatus` state machine
   656- [x] Implement round-robin account selection
   657- [x] Implement quota detection (429 message parsing)
   658- [x] Implement cooldown management
   659- [x] Implement proactive background refresh task
   660- [x] Unit tests for selection, failover, cooldown transitions, quota detection
   661
   662### Phase 4: Gateway Integration
   663
   664- [x] Implement `AnthropicOAuthProvider` using pool + auth crates
   665- [x] Header injection: Bearer token, beta flags, User-Agent, dangerous-direct-browser-access
   666- [x] System prompt prefix injection (body modification for Opus/Sonnet)
   667- [x] Model extraction from request body
   668- [x] Extend config.rs with `[oauth]` section parsing
   669- [x] Mode detection: passthrough vs oauth_pool
   670- [x] Extend health endpoint with pool status
   671- [x] Add pool metrics
   672- [x] Integration tests with mock Anthropic API
   673
   674### Phase 5: Admin API
   675
   676- [x] Implement admin router on separate port
   677- [x] `GET /admin/accounts`  list with pool status
   678- [x] `POST /admin/accounts/init-oauth`  generate PKCE, return authorization URL
   679- [x] `POST /admin/accounts/complete-oauth`  exchange code, store credentials, add to pool
   680- [x] `DELETE /admin/accounts/{id}`  remove from pool, update credential file
   681- [x] `GET /admin/pool`  pool summary
   682
   683### Phase 6: Deployment
   684
   685- [x] Add PVC manifest for credential storage
   686- [x] Update ConfigMap with `[oauth]` section
   687- [x] Optional admin Service manifest
   688- [x] Update RUNBOOK.md with OAuth operational procedures
   689- [x] E2E test: add account  proxy request  verify Claude API response
   690
   691---
   692
   693## Success Criteria
   694
   695- [x] Backward compatible: existing `[[headers]]` config works unchanged
   696- [x] OAuth PKCE flow completes: admin adds account via CLI/API
   697- [x] Token auto-refresh: no manual token management after initial auth
   698- [x] Pool failover: quota exhaustion on account A  automatic switch to account B
   699- [x] System prompt injection: Opus/Sonnet requests get required prefix
   700- [x] Health endpoint: reports pool status (available/cooling/disabled per account)
   701- [x] Credential persistence: pod restart preserves OAuth tokens
   702- [x] Zero client credentials: ForgeFlare/Claude Code send bare requests
   703
   704---
   705
   706## Security Considerations
   707
   7081. **Credential isolation**: Each account's OAuth tokens independently managed
   7092. **No credential exposure**: Admin API and health endpoint show account IDs and status, never tokens
   7103. **File permissions**: Credential file 0600, owned by container user
   7114. **Admin API isolation**: Separate port, not exposed via Tailscale Ingress
   7125. **System prompt prefix**: Required by Anthropic for Opus/Sonnet  gateway handles this transparently
   7136. **PKCE**: All OAuth flows use S256 challenge to prevent code interception
   714
   715---
   716
   717## Out of Scope
   718
   719- **Non-Anthropic providers**  multi-provider trait is designed in, but only Anthropic is implemented
   720- **Web UI for account management**  admin API is CLI/curl-driven. Web UI is a future enhancement.
   721- **Telemetry/session tracking**  Aperture handles this upstream. The gateway is auth-only.
   722- **Rate limiting / access control**  Aperture handles per-user access. The gateway serves all tailnet traffic equally.
   723- **Console OAuth mode**  only Max (claude.ai) authorization is supported. API key creation via OAuth is not needed.
   724
   725---
   726
   727## Header Discovery Maintenance
   728
   729When Anthropic updates Claude CLI, required headers may change. Maintenance procedure:
   730
   7311. Install updated Claude CLI
   7322. Sniff traffic via mitmproxy: `mitmdump --set flow_detail=4 -p 8888`
   7333. Route CLI through proxy: `HTTPS_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:8888 claude --print "hello"`
   7344. Compare captured headers against constants in `anthropic-auth`
   7355. Update constants, run tests
   736
   737---
   738
   739## References
   740
   741- Loom `specs/claude-subscription-auth.md`  OAuth 2.0 PKCE implementation details
   742- Loom `specs/anthropic-oauth-pool.md`  Subscription pooling architecture
   743- Loom `specs/anthropic-max-pool-management.md`  Admin API patterns
   744- `aperture/aperture.md`  Multi-provider gateway reference architecture
   745- `specs/oauth-proxy.md`  Current implementation (passthrough header injector)
   746- [OAuth 2.0 PKCE RFC 7636](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636)
   747- [Anthropic MAX Plan Implementation Guide](https://raw.githubusercontent.REDACTED.md)
   748
   749---
   750
   751*Spec-first. Types define contract. State machine is the program.*
   752

file.content:
# Spec: Anthropic OAuth Gateway

**Status:** Complete
**Created:** 2026-02-09
**Author:** Brent + Cowork
**Supersedes:** `oauth-proxy.md` (header injector  full OAuth gateway)

---

## Overview

Evolve the anthropic-oauth-proxy from a static header injector into a full OAuth 2.0 gateway with subscription pooling. The proxy currently passes through client-provided `Authorization` headers and injects `anthropic-beta: oauth-2025-04-20`. The target state manages its own OAuth credentials: PKCE authentication flow, automatic token refresh, round-robin subscription pooling with quota failover, and the full Anthropic header contract.

Clients on the tailnet send unauthenticated requests. The gateway handles everything.

**Pins:**

| Reference | What it provides |
|-----------|-----------------|
| Loom `specs/claude-subscription-auth.md` | OAuth 2.0 PKCE flow, token exchange/refresh, credential storage, header contract |
| Loom `specs/anthropic-oauth-pool.md` | Subscription pooling, round-robin failover, quota detection, health reporting |
| Loom `specs/anthropic-max-pool-management.md` | Admin API patterns, proactive token refresh, account lifecycle |
| Aperture by Tailscale | Multi-provider gateway architecture, Tailscale identity, model-based routing |

**Design Principles (carried forward):**

| Principle | Implementation |
|-----------|----------------|
| Single responsibility | One binary, one provider (Anthropic) |
| Provider trait | Multi-provider interface designed in, only Anthropic implemented |
| Tailnet-native | MagicDNS identity via Tailscale Operator |
| Pure state machines | Auth state, pool state, service lifecycle  all explicit |
| Zero client credentials | Clients send bare requests; gateway injects everything |

---

## Architecture

```text

                              Tailnet                                      
                                                                           
              
   Aperture   Tailscale     anthropic-oauth-proxy         
   (http://ai/)     Operator                                         
         Ingress                
                               OAuth Pool             
                                         
  ForgeFlare     Max1   Max2 ...     
                                                  
                                                     
                                  
   Claude                                  
   Code                                                              
                                  
                                            Header Injection          
                                            + System Prompt Gate      
                                            + Token Refresh           
                                              
                                          
                                                                         
                                                                         
                                              api.anthropic.com           

```

MagicDNS hostname remains `anthropic-oauth-proxy`. Same Tailscale Ingress, same K8s footprint. Binary name unchanged. The upgrade is internal.

---

## Auth Modes

The gateway supports two mutually exclusive auth modes, determined at startup:

| Mode | Source | Behavior |
|------|--------|----------|
| **Passthrough** (current) | `[headers]` config with no `[oauth]` section | Inject static headers, pass through client Authorization. Backward compatible. |
| **OAuth Pool** | `[oauth]` section present | Manage credentials, inject Bearer token + full header contract. Client Authorization ignored. |

This preserves backward compatibility. Existing deployments with `[[headers]]` config continue to work. Adding an `[oauth]` section activates the new behavior.

---

## Multi-Provider Interface

The gateway is Anthropic-only but the provider abstraction is designed for future extension.

### Provider Trait

```rust
/// Trait for LLM provider authentication and request preparation.
/// Anthropic is the only implementation. Designed for future providers
/// (OpenAI, Google) without breaking changes.
pub trait Provider: Send + Sync {
    /// Provider identifier (e.g., "anthropic")
    fn id(&self) -> &str;

    /// Prepare an outbound request: inject auth headers, modify body if needed.
    /// Called once per proxy attempt (not per retry).
    async fn prepare_request(
        &self,
        request: &mut RequestBuilder,
        body: &mut serde_json::Value,
    ) -> Result<(), ProviderError>;

    /// Classify an upstream error for failover decisions.
    fn classify_error(&self, status: u16, body: &str) -> ErrorClassification;

    /// Report an error back to the provider (e.g., mark account as cooling).
    async fn report_error(
        &self,
        classification: ErrorClassification,
    ) -> Result<(), ProviderError>;

    /// Health status for the /health endpoint.
    async fn health(&self) -> ProviderHealth;
}
```

### Error Classification

```rust
#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy)]
pub enum ErrorClassification {
    /// Transient error, retry on same account (via existing retry loop)
    Transient,
    /// Quota exhausted, failover to next account in pool
    QuotaExceeded,
    /// Permanent error (bad credentials), disable account
    Permanent,
}
```

---

## OAuth Implementation

### Constants

```rust
/// Anthropic's public OAuth client ID (same as Claude CLI)
pub const ANTHROPIC_CLIENT_ID: &str = "9d1c250a-e61b-44d9-88ed-5944d1962f5e";

/// OAuth redirect URI
pub const REDIRECT_URI: &str = "https://console.anthropic.com/oauth/code/callback";

/// Token endpoint
pub const TOKEN_ENDPOINT: &str = "https://console.anthropic.com/v1/oauth/token";

/// Authorization endpoint (Pro/Max subscriptions)
pub const AUTHORIZE_ENDPOINT: &str = "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize";

/// OAuth scopes (user:sessions:claude_code required for Sonnet/Opus)
/// Note: org:create_api_key is NOT included  that's for Console OAuth (API key creation),
/// which is out of scope. This gateway only does Max (claude.ai) authorization.
pub const SCOPES: &str = "user:profile user:inference user:sessions:claude_code";

/// Required system prompt prefix for Opus/Sonnet access
pub const REQUIRED_SYSTEM_PROMPT_PREFIX: &str =
    "You are Claude Code, Anthropic's official CLI for Claude.";
```

### PKCE Flow

Standard OAuth 2.0 with PKCE (RFC 7636). No client secret (public client).

```text
Admin CLI                    Gateway                     claude.ai
                                                           
      add-account                                          
                                
                                 Generate PKCE pair        
                                 (verifier + S256 challenge)
      authorization_url                                    
                                
                                                           
      Open browser 
                                                           
      User authorizes                                      
    
                                                           
      Paste code#{state}                                   
                                
                                 POST /v1/oauth/token      
                               
                                 {access, refresh, expires}
                               
                                                           
                                 Store credentials         
                                 Add to pool (hot-reload)  
      Account added                                        
                                
```

### Credential Storage

JSON file on disk, keyed by account ID. Mounted as a PersistentVolume in K8s.

```json
{
  "claude-max-1": {
    "type": "oauth",
    "refresh": "rt_abc123...",
    "access": "at_xyz789...",
    "expires": 1735500000000
  },
  "claude-max-2": {
    "type": "oauth",
    "refresh": "rt_def456...",
    "access": "at_uvw000...",
    "expires": 1735500100000
  }
}
```

File permissions: `0600`, owned by container UID 1000 (non-root). Never exposed via API. Health endpoint shows account IDs and status only.

**Atomic writes:** Credential file updates use write-to-temp + atomic rename to prevent corruption on crash mid-write. All writes acquire an in-memory `Mutex` to prevent concurrent modification from request-time refresh and background refresh tasks.

**Cold start:** If credential file does not exist, create it as `{}`. Pool starts with zero accounts, health reports `unhealthy` with `accounts_total: 0`. First request returns 503 until an account is added via admin API.

---

## Subscription Pool

### Account State Machine

```rust
#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq)]
pub enum AccountStatus {
    /// Ready to serve requests
    Available,
    /// Hit 5-hour quota, cooling down
    CoolingDown { until: Instant },
    /// Permanently failed (invalid credentials, revoked token)
    Disabled,
}
```

### State Transitions

| Current | Trigger | New State | Action |
|---------|---------|-----------|--------|
| `Available` | Request succeeds | `Available` | None |
| `Available` | 429 + quota message | `CoolingDown` | Log, failover to next |
| `Available` | 401/403 | `Disabled` | Log error, failover |
| `Available` | Transient error | `Available` | Retry (existing retry loop) |
| `CoolingDown` | Cooldown expired | `Available` | Log recovery |
| `CoolingDown` | Token refresh fails | `Disabled` | Log error |
| `Disabled` | Admin removes | (removed) | Persist credential file |

State transitions apply uniformly: a 401/403 from token refresh (request-time or background) transitions the account to `Disabled` regardless of previous state. `CoolingDown` accounts that fail background refresh go directly to `Disabled`.

### Account Selection (Round-Robin)

1. Start from `next_index`
2. Scan N accounts for `Available` status
3. Check `CoolingDown` accounts  if cooldown expired, transition to `Available`
4. Select first `Available`, advance `next_index`
5. If none available  503 Service Unavailable:
```json
{
  "error": {
    "type": "pool_exhausted",
    "message": "All accounts exhausted",
    "pool": {
      "accounts_total": 2,
      "accounts_available": 0,
      "accounts_cooling": 2,
      "accounts_disabled": 0
    }
  }
}
```

### Quota Detection

Not all 429s are quota exhaustion. The classifier inspects the error message body:

| HTTP Status | Message Pattern | Classification |
|-------------|----------------|----------------|
| 429 | Contains "5-hour", "5 hour", "rolling window", "usage limit for your plan", "subscription usage limit" | `QuotaExceeded` |
| 429 | Other rate limit messages | `Transient` |
| 401, 403 | Any | `Permanent` |
| 408, 500, 502, 503, 504 | Any | `Transient` |

### Cooldown

Default: 2 hours (configurable via `cooldown_secs`). Conservative  the actual 5-hour window is rolling, so 2h is a safe recovery margin.

---

## Request Pipeline

The gateway modifies both headers and body before forwarding.

### Header Injection (OAuth Mode)

| Header | Value | Notes |
|--------|-------|-------|
| `Authorization` | `Bearer {access_token}` | From selected pool account. Client-provided Authorization is **ignored** (stripped before injection). |
| `anthropic-beta` | `oauth-2025-04-20,interleaved-thinking-2025-05-14,context-management-2025-06-27` | Must include `oauth-2025-04-20` |
| `anthropic-dangerous-direct-browser-access` | `true` | Required for OAuth |
| `user-agent` | `claude-cli/2.0.76 (external, sdk-cli)` | Must match Claude CLI format |
| `anthropic-version` | `2023-06-01` | API version |

Client-provided `anthropic-beta` values are merged (deduplicated) with the required set.

### System Prompt Prefix Injection

For Opus and Sonnet models, the system prompt **must** start with the exact phrase:

```text
You are Claude Code, Anthropic's official CLI for Claude.
```

The gateway inspects the request body:

| Condition | Action |
|-----------|--------|
| No `system` field | Inject `system` with required prefix |
| `system` field exists, missing prefix | Prepend prefix + `" "` + existing content |
| `system` field exists, has prefix | No modification |
| Model is Haiku | No modification (prefix not required) |

```rust
fn inject_system_prompt(body: &mut serde_json::Value, model: &str) {
    // Haiku doesn't need the prefix
    if model.contains("haiku") {
        return;
    }

    let prefix = REQUIRED_SYSTEM_PROMPT_PREFIX;

    match body.get_mut("system") {
        None => {
            body["system"] = serde_json::Value::String(prefix.to_string());
        }
        Some(system) => {
            if let Some(s) = system.as_str() {
                if !s.starts_with(prefix) {
                    *system = serde_json::Value::String(
                        format!("{} {}", prefix, s)
                    );
                }
            }
        }
    }
}
```

### Model Extraction

The gateway extracts the model name from the request body to determine:

1. Whether system prompt injection is needed (non-Haiku)
2. Logging and metrics labels

```rust
fn extract_model(body: &serde_json::Value) -> Option<&str> {
    body.get("model").and_then(|v| v.as_str())
}
```

### Body Handling Path

The current proxy forwards request bodies as opaque bytes. OAuth mode requires body modification (system prompt injection), which means `bytes  serde_json::Value  modify  serialize  forward`. This is the riskiest refactor  it touches the hot path and introduces a JSON round-trip that could alter field ordering, whitespace, or unicode escapes.

| Mode | Body Path | Cost |
|------|-----------|------|
| Passthrough | Opaque bytes forwarded unchanged | Zero overhead (existing behavior) |
| OAuth | Deserialize  modify  serialize | JSON round-trip on every request |

Design choice: **always deserialize in OAuth mode.** The latency of an Anthropic API call (seconds) dwarfs JSON serde time (microseconds). Optimizing with string-scan peeking adds complexity for negligible gain at this scale.

The `Provider` trait receives `&mut serde_json::Value` so providers that don't need body modification (future OpenAI provider) can simply no-op. The deserialization happens once in `proxy.rs` before calling `provider.prepare_request()`, only when the provider is in OAuth mode.

---

## Token Refresh

### Auto-Refresh on Request

Before each proxied request, the gateway checks the selected account's token expiration:

| Condition | Action |
|-----------|--------|
| Token valid (>60s remaining) | Use current access token |
| Token expiring (<60s) or expired | Refresh via `POST /v1/oauth/token` with `grant_type=refresh_token` |
| Refresh succeeds | Update in-memory + persist to credential file |
| Refresh fails | Mark account `Disabled`, failover to next |

### Proactive Background Refresh

A background tokio task runs independently of request flow:

| Parameter | Default | Config Key |
|-----------|---------|------------|
| Check interval | 5 minutes | `refresh_interval_secs` |
| Refresh threshold | 15 minutes | `refresh_threshold_secs` |

The task iterates all accounts, refreshing any token expiring within the threshold. This prevents mid-request refresh latency under normal operation.

---

## Configuration

### File Format (TOML)

```toml
# anthropic-oauth-proxy.toml

[proxy]
listen_addr = "0.0.0.0:8080"
upstream_url = "https://api.anthropic.com"
timeout_secs = 60
max_connections = 1000

# OAuth pool configuration (presence activates OAuth mode)
[oauth]
credential_file = "/data/credentials.json"
cooldown_secs = 7200          # 2 hours
refresh_interval_secs = 300   # 5 minutes
refresh_threshold_secs = 900  # 15 minutes

# Static accounts to load from credential file at startup
# New accounts can be added at runtime via admin API
providers = ["claude-max-1", "claude-max-2"]

# Admin API (for account management)
[admin]
enabled = true
listen_addr = "0.0.0.0:9090"  # Separate port, not exposed via Ingress
```

When `[oauth]` is absent, the gateway falls back to passthrough mode using `[[headers]]` (backward compatible with current config). If both `[oauth]` and `[[headers]]` are present, `[oauth]` takes precedence and `[[headers]]` is ignored.

### Environment Variables

| Variable | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| `CONFIG_PATH` | Config file path (existing) |
| `LOG_LEVEL` | Logging verbosity (existing) |
| `CREDENTIAL_FILE` | Override credential file path |

---

## Admin API

Separate listener on a non-Ingress port. Accessed via `kubectl port-forward` (authenticated by Kubernetes kubeconfig). Not exposed to the tailnet.

**Single-pod requirement:** PKCE state is in-memory. The gateway runs as a single-replica Deployment. Multi-pod is not supported for the admin API flow (init-oauth on pod A, complete-oauth on pod B would fail). This is acceptable  account management is a rare admin operation, not a hot path.

### Endpoints

| Method | Path | Description |
|--------|------|-------------|
| `GET` | `/admin/accounts` | List accounts with status |
| `POST` | `/admin/accounts/init-oauth` | Start OAuth PKCE flow, returns authorization URL |
| `POST` | `/admin/accounts/complete-oauth` | Complete OAuth flow with authorization code |
| `DELETE` | `/admin/accounts/{id}` | Remove account from pool |
| `GET` | `/admin/pool` | Pool status summary |

### Account ID Generation

New accounts are assigned IDs in the format `claude-max-{unix_timestamp}` (e.g., `claude-max-1739059200`). Must be unique within the credential file.

### PKCE State Storage

Between `init-oauth` and `complete-oauth`, the gateway stores PKCE verifiers in an in-memory `HashMap<String, PkceState>` keyed by account ID. Entries expire after 10 minutes. No persistence needed  if the gateway restarts mid-flow, the admin simply re-initiates.

```rust
struct PkceState {
    verifier: String,
    created_at: Instant,
}
```

### Init OAuth Response

```json
{
  "authorization_url": "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize?client_id=...&code_challenge=...&state=...",
  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
  "instructions": "Open the URL in a browser, authorize, then paste the code to complete-oauth"
}
```

### Complete OAuth Request

```json
{
  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
  "code": "{authorization_code}#{state}"
}
```

---

## Health Endpoint (Upgraded)

The existing `/health` endpoint expands to include pool status:

### Passthrough Mode (backward compatible)

```json
{
  "status": "healthy",
  "mode": "passthrough",
  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
  "requests_served": 12345,
  "errors_total": 0
}
```

### OAuth Pool Mode

```json
{
  "status": "healthy",
  "mode": "oauth_pool",
  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
  "requests_served": 12345,
  "errors_total": 0,
  "pool": {
    "accounts_total": 3,
    "accounts_available": 2,
    "accounts_cooling": 1,
    "accounts_disabled": 0,
    "accounts": [
      { "id": "claude-max-1", "status": "available" },
      { "id": "claude-max-2", "status": "cooling_down", "cooldown_remaining_secs": 3600 },
      { "id": "claude-max-3", "status": "available" }
    ]
  }
}
```

### Health Status Mapping

| Pool State | Status |
|------------|--------|
| All available | `healthy` |
| 1 available, some cooling/disabled | `degraded` |
| All cooling or disabled | `unhealthy` (still returns 200  Kubernetes probes check JSON) |

---

## Metrics (Extended)

Existing metrics are preserved. New metrics for OAuth:

| Metric | Type | Labels |
|--------|------|--------|
| `proxy_requests_total` | Counter | `status`, `method` (existing) |
| `proxy_request_duration_seconds` | Histogram | `status` (existing) |
| `proxy_upstream_errors_total` | Counter | `error_type` (existing) |
| `pool_account_status` | Gauge | `account_id`, `status` |
| `pool_failovers_total` | Counter | `from_account`, `reason` |
| `pool_token_refreshes_total` | Counter | `account_id`, `result` |
| `pool_quota_exhaustions_total` | Counter | `account_id` |

---

## Project Structure (Target)

```text
crates/
  common/               # Shared types: error types (existing)
  provider/             # NEW: Provider trait, ErrorClassification
  anthropic-auth/       # NEW: OAuth PKCE, token refresh, credential storage
  anthropic-pool/       # NEW: Subscription pool, round-robin, failover
services/
  oauth-proxy/          # Existing binary, upgraded
    src/
      main.rs           # Entry point (existing, extended)
      config.rs         # Config (existing, extended with [oauth] section)
      service.rs        # Service state machine (existing)
      proxy.rs          # HTTP proxy (existing, call provider.prepare_request())
      metrics.rs        # Metrics (existing, extended)
      admin.rs          # NEW: Admin API routes
      provider_impl.rs  # NEW: AnthropicProvider implementing Provider trait
specs/
  oauth-proxy.md              # Original spec (Complete, preserved)
  anthropic-oauth-gateway.md  # This spec
```

### Crate Dependency Graph

```text
oauth-proxy (binary)
   common
   provider          (trait definition)
   anthropic-auth    (PKCE, token refresh, credentials)
   anthropic-pool    (pool state, selection, failover)
         anthropic-auth
```

---

## Deployment Changes

### PersistentVolumeClaim

Credential file must survive pod restarts. Add a PVC mounted at `/data/`:

```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
metadata:
  name: anthropic-oauth-credentials
  namespace: tailnet
spec:
  accessModes: [ReadWriteOnce]
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Mi
```

### ConfigMap Update

Add `[oauth]` section to the existing ConfigMap. Backward compatible  removing the section reverts to passthrough mode.

### Service (Admin)

Optional second Service on port 9090 for admin API. Not exposed via Ingress. Accessible via `kubectl port-forward` or from within the cluster.

### No Other Changes

Same Deployment, same Ingress, same MagicDNS hostname, same container image tag pattern. The binary detects its mode from config.

---

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Provider Abstraction + Mode Detection

- [x] Create `crates/provider/` with `Provider` trait and `ErrorClassification`
- [x] Create `PassthroughProvider` implementing `Provider` trait (wraps current header injection logic)
- [x] Extend `config.rs` with `[oauth]` section parsing and mode detection
- [x] Refactor `proxy.rs` to call `provider.prepare_request()` instead of inline header injection
- [x] Body handling fork: passthrough = opaque bytes, oauth = deserialize (stubbed  passthrough provider uses opaque path)
- [x] All existing tests pass, behavior unchanged (passthrough provider reproduces current behavior exactly)

### Phase 2: OAuth Foundation

- [x] Create `crates/anthropic-auth/` with PKCE generation (verifier + S256 challenge)
- [x] Implement token exchange (`authorization_code` grant)
- [x] Implement token refresh (`refresh_token` grant)
- [x] Implement credential file storage (read/write JSON, 0600 permissions)
- [x] Unit tests for PKCE, exchange, refresh, storage

### Phase 3: Subscription Pool

- [x] Create `crates/anthropic-pool/` with `AccountStatus` state machine
- [x] Implement round-robin account selection
- [x] Implement quota detection (429 message parsing)
- [x] Implement cooldown management
- [x] Implement proactive background refresh task
- [x] Unit tests for selection, failover, cooldown transitions, quota detection

### Phase 4: Gateway Integration

- [x] Implement `AnthropicOAuthProvider` using pool + auth crates
- [x] Header injection: Bearer token, beta flags, User-Agent, dangerous-direct-browser-access
- [x] System prompt prefix injection (body modification for Opus/Sonnet)
- [x] Model extraction from request body
- [x] Extend config.rs with `[oauth]` section parsing
- [x] Mode detection: passthrough vs oauth_pool
- [x] Extend health endpoint with pool status
- [x] Add pool metrics
- [x] Integration tests with mock Anthropic API

### Phase 5: Admin API

- [x] Implement admin router on separate port
- [x] `GET /admin/accounts`  list with pool status
- [x] `POST /admin/accounts/init-oauth`  generate PKCE, return authorization URL
- [x] `POST /admin/accounts/complete-oauth`  exchange code, store credentials, add to pool
- [x] `DELETE /admin/accounts/{id}`  remove from pool, update credential file
- [x] `GET /admin/pool`  pool summary

### Phase 6: Deployment

- [x] Add PVC manifest for credential storage
- [x] Update ConfigMap with `[oauth]` section
- [x] Optional admin Service manifest
- [x] Update RUNBOOK.md with OAuth operational procedures
- [x] E2E test: add account  proxy request  verify Claude API response

---

## Success Criteria

- [x] Backward compatible: existing `[[headers]]` config works unchanged
- [x] OAuth PKCE flow completes: admin adds account via CLI/API
- [x] Token auto-refresh: no manual token management after initial auth
- [x] Pool failover: quota exhaustion on account A  automatic switch to account B
- [x] System prompt injection: Opus/Sonnet requests get required prefix
- [x] Health endpoint: reports pool status (available/cooling/disabled per account)
- [x] Credential persistence: pod restart preserves OAuth tokens
- [x] Zero client credentials: ForgeFlare/Claude Code send bare requests

---

## Security Considerations

1. **Credential isolation**: Each account's OAuth tokens independently managed
2. **No credential exposure**: Admin API and health endpoint show account IDs and status, never tokens
3. **File permissions**: Credential file 0600, owned by container user
4. **Admin API isolation**: Separate port, not exposed via Tailscale Ingress
5. **System prompt prefix**: Required by Anthropic for Opus/Sonnet  gateway handles this transparently
6. **PKCE**: All OAuth flows use S256 challenge to prevent code interception

---

## Out of Scope

- **Non-Anthropic providers**  multi-provider trait is designed in, but only Anthropic is implemented
- **Web UI for account management**  admin API is CLI/curl-driven. Web UI is a future enhancement.
- **Telemetry/session tracking**  Aperture handles this upstream. The gateway is auth-only.
- **Rate limiting / access control**  Aperture handles per-user access. The gateway serves all tailnet traffic equally.
- **Console OAuth mode**  only Max (claude.ai) authorization is supported. API key creation via OAuth is not needed.

---

## Header Discovery Maintenance

When Anthropic updates Claude CLI, required headers may change. Maintenance procedure:

1. Install updated Claude CLI
2. Sniff traffic via mitmproxy: `mitmdump --set flow_detail=4 -p 8888`
3. Route CLI through proxy: `HTTPS_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:8888 claude --print "hello"`
4. Compare captured headers against constants in `anthropic-auth`
5. Update constants, run tests

---

## References

- Loom `specs/claude-subscription-auth.md`  OAuth 2.0 PKCE implementation details
- Loom `specs/anthropic-oauth-pool.md`  Subscription pooling architecture
- Loom `specs/anthropic-max-pool-management.md`  Admin API patterns
- `aperture/aperture.md`  Multi-provider gateway reference architecture
- `specs/oauth-proxy.md`  Current implementation (passthrough header injector)
- [OAuth 2.0 PKCE RFC 7636](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636)
- [Anthropic MAX Plan Implementation Guide](https://raw.githubusercontent.REDACTED.md)

---

*Spec-first. Types define contract. State machine is the program.*

content.content:
1# Anthropic OAuth Proxy  Operational Runbook
     2
     3This runbook covers deployment, operation, monitoring, and troubleshooting of the anthropic-oauth-proxy service. The proxy supports two modes: passthrough (static header injection) and OAuth pool (PKCE auth, token refresh, subscription pooling).
     4
     5## Architecture
     6
     7The pod contains a single container. The Tailscale Operator manages tailnet connectivity via an Ingress resource that creates a proxy StatefulSet routing traffic from the tailnet to the Service ClusterIP.
     8
     9```text
    10                    Tailnet
    11      +----------+         +---------------------+
    12      | Aperture | ------> | Tailscale Operator   |
    13      | (http://ai/)       | proxy (StatefulSet)  |
    14      +----------+         +----------+----------+
    15                                      |
    16                                      v
    17                           +---------------------+       +-----------+
    18                           | anthropic-oauth-proxy| ----> | Anthropic |
    19                           | (single container)   |      | API       |
    20                           +---------------------+       +-----------+
    21                            MagicDNS: anthropic-oauth-proxy
    22                            Proxy: 8080  |  Admin: 9090
    23```
    24
    25In passthrough mode, the proxy injects the `anthropic-beta: oauth-2025-04-20` header and forwards to `https://api.anthropic.com`. In OAuth mode, it manages Bearer tokens from a pool of Claude Max subscriptions, handles automatic token refresh, and injects the full Anthropic header contract (anthropic-beta, anthropic-version, user-agent, system prompt). TLS termination for inbound traffic is handled by the tailnet WireGuard encryption. Outbound TLS to Anthropic uses `reqwest` with `rustls`.
    26
    27## Deployment
    28
    29### Initial Deploy
    30
    31No secrets are required. The container image is public on GHCR (anonymous pull). Tailnet authentication is handled by the Tailscale Operator.
    32
    33```bash
    34kubectl apply -k k8s/
    35```
    36
    37This creates the namespace, ServiceAccount, ConfigMap, PVC, Deployment, Services (proxy + admin), and Ingress. The Tailscale Operator detects the Ingress and creates a StatefulSet to proxy from the tailnet to the ClusterIP.
    38
    39### Verify Deployment
    40
    41```bash
    42kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get pods
    43kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy logs deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
    44```
    45
    46A healthy startup sequence in the logs (JSON structured):
    47
    48```text
    49{"message":"starting anthropic-oauth-proxy",...}
    50{"message":"loading configuration","path":"/etc/anthropic-oauth-proxy/config.toml",...}
    51{"message":"configuration loaded","listen_addr":"0.0.0.0:8080",...}
    52{"message":"state: Starting",...}
    53{"message":"state: Running  accepting requests","addr":"0.0.0.0:8080",...}
    54```
    55
    56Verify the Tailscale Operator created its proxy StatefulSet:
    57
    58```bash
    59kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get statefulset
    60```
    61
    62### Switching to OAuth Mode
    63
    64To switch from passthrough to OAuth mode, update the ConfigMap to uncomment the `[oauth]` and `[admin]` sections (and optionally remove `[[headers]]`  `[oauth]` takes precedence automatically). Then restart the deployment:
    65
    66```bash
    67kubectl apply -k k8s/
    68kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout restart deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
    69```
    70
    71The proxy starts in OAuth mode with an empty pool. Add accounts via the admin API (see below).
    72
    73### Updating Configuration
    74
    75The ConfigMap at `k8s/configmap.yaml` holds the TOML configuration. After editing:
    76
    77```bash
    78kubectl apply -k k8s/
    79kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout restart deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
    80```
    81
    82### Rollback
    83
    84If a deployment introduces issues, roll back to the previous revision:
    85
    86```bash
    87kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout undo deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
    88kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout status deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
    89```
    90
    91Kubernetes retains the previous ReplicaSet by default, so `rollout undo` restores both the container image and the ConfigMap hash from the prior revision. For rollbacks beyond one revision, use `rollout undo --to-revision=<N>` where `N` is from `rollout history`.
    92
    93## OAuth Account Management
    94
    95Accounts are managed via the admin API on port 9090. The admin port is not exposed via Ingress  access it through `kubectl port-forward`.
    96
    97### Accessing the Admin API
    98
    99```bash
   100kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy port-forward deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy 9090:9090
   101```
   102
   103All admin commands below assume port-forwarding is active.
   104
   105### Adding an Account (PKCE Flow)
   106
   107Step 1  Initiate the OAuth flow:
   108
   109```bash
   110curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts/init-oauth | jq .
   111```
   112
   113Response:
   114
   115```json
   116{
   117  "authorization_url": "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize?client_id=...&code_challenge=...",
   118  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
   119  "instructions": "Open the URL in a browser, authorize, then paste the code to complete-oauth"
   120}
   121```
   122
   123Step 2  Open the `authorization_url` in a browser and authorize with the Claude Max account. After authorization, the browser redirects to a page showing a `code#state` value.
   124
   125Step 3  Complete the flow:
   126
   127```bash
   128curl -s -X POST http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts/complete-oauth \
   129  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
   130  -d '{"account_id": "claude-max-1739059200", "code": "AUTH_CODE#STATE"}' | jq .
   131```
   132
   133The PKCE state expires after 10 minutes. If Step 3 is not completed in time, start over from Step 1.
   134
   135### Listing Accounts
   136
   137```bash
   138curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts | jq .
   139```
   140
   141Response includes account IDs and status (available, cooling_down, disabled). Tokens are never exposed.
   142
   143### Removing an Account
   144
   145```bash
   146curl -s -X DELETE http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts/claude-max-1739059200 | jq .
   147```
   148
   149Removes the account from the pool and credential store. Idempotent.
   150
   151### Pool Status
   152
   153```bash
   154curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/pool | jq .
   155```
   156
   157Returns per-account status, cooldown timers, and overall pool health.
   158
   159### Credential Persistence
   160
   161OAuth credentials are stored in `/data/credentials.json` on a PersistentVolumeClaim. Pod restarts preserve tokens  no need to re-authenticate accounts after restart.
   162
   163The single-replica constraint exists because PKCE state is held in-memory. Running multiple pods would split the init/complete flow across pods. This does not affect credential persistence (PVC survives pod restarts).
   164
   165## Endpoints
   166
   167| Path | Port | Purpose | Response |
   168|------|------|---------|----------|
   169| `GET /health` | 8080 | Startup, liveness, readiness probe | JSON with status, uptime, pool status |
   170| `GET /metrics` | 8080 | Prometheus scrape target | Text exposition format |
   171| `* /*` | 8080 | Proxy fallback | Forwards to upstream |
   172| `GET /admin/accounts` | 9090 | List accounts | JSON account list |
   173| `POST /admin/accounts/init-oauth` | 9090 | Start PKCE flow | JSON with auth URL |
   174| `POST /admin/accounts/complete-oauth` | 9090 | Exchange code | JSON confirmation |
   175| `DELETE /admin/accounts/{id}` | 9090 | Remove account | JSON confirmation |
   176| `GET /admin/pool` | 9090 | Pool health summary | JSON pool status |
   177
   178### Health Endpoint Response
   179
   180The health endpoint always returns HTTP 200 when the listener is bound. The `status` field indicates pool health.
   181
   182Passthrough mode:
   183
   184```json
   185{
   186  "status": "healthy",
   187  "mode": "passthrough",
   188  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   189  "requests_served": 12345,
   190  "errors_total": 0
   191}
   192```
   193
   194OAuth mode:
   195
   196```json
   197{
   198  "status": "degraded",
   199  "mode": "anthropic",
   200  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   201  "requests_served": 12345,
   202  "errors_total": 0,
   203  "pool": {
   204    "accounts_total": 3,
   205    "accounts_available": 2,
   206    "accounts_cooling": 1,
   207    "accounts_disabled": 0,
   208    "accounts": [
   209      { "id": "claude-max-1", "status": "available" },
   210      { "id": "claude-max-2", "status": "cooling_down", "cooldown_remaining_secs": 3600 },
   211      { "id": "claude-max-3", "status": "available" }
   212    ]
   213  }
   214}
   215```
   216
   217Status mapping: all available = `healthy`, some cooling/disabled = `degraded`, all cooling/disabled = `unhealthy`.
   218
   219## Monitoring
   220
   221### Prometheus Metrics
   222
   223Scrape `GET /metrics` on port 8080. Metrics emitted:
   224
   225`proxy_requests_total` (counter) with labels `status` and `method` tracks completed proxy requests. Use this for request rate and error rate calculations.
   226
   227`proxy_request_duration_seconds` (histogram) with label `status` and bucket boundaries from 5ms to 60s. Use `histogram_quantile()` in PromQL to compute latency percentiles (p50, p90, p99) from the histogram buckets at query time.
   228
   229`proxy_upstream_errors_total` (counter) with label `error_type` tracks upstream failures. Error types: `timeout` (upstream did not respond within `timeout_secs`), `connection` (TCP connection to upstream failed), `invalid_request` (request body exceeded 10 MiB limit or malformed request).
   230
   231OAuth mode adds four additional metrics:
   232
   233`pool_account_status` (gauge) with labels `account_id` and `status`. Tracks the current state of each account in the pool (available, cooling_down, disabled).
   234
   235`pool_failovers_total` (counter) with labels `from_account` and `reason`. Incremented when the proxy fails over from one account to the next due to quota exhaustion or permanent error.
   236
   237`pool_token_refreshes_total` (counter) with labels `account_id` and `result`. Tracks token refresh attempts (success or failure).
   238
   239`pool_quota_exhaustions_total` (counter) with label `account_id`. Incremented when an account hits its usage quota (429 with quota message).
   240
   241### Key Alerts
   242
   243Alert on sustained upstream errors:
   244
   245```text
   246rate(proxy_upstream_errors_total[5m]) > 0.1
   247```
   248
   249Alert on p99 latency approaching the 60s timeout. The `sum by (le)` aggregation is required because the histogram carries a `status` label:
   250
   251```text
   252histogram_quantile(0.99, sum by (le) (rate(proxy_request_duration_seconds_bucket[5m]))) > 30
   253```
   254
   255Alert when all pool accounts are exhausted (OAuth mode). This fires when no accounts are available:
   256
   257```text
   258sum(pool_account_status{status="available"}) == 0
   259```
   260
   261Alert on high failover rate indicating quota pressure across accounts:
   262
   263```text
   264rate(pool_failovers_total[5m]) > 0.05
   265```
   266
   267### Token Refresh Troubleshooting
   268
   269If `pool_token_refreshes_total{result="failure"}` is incrementing, accounts are failing to refresh their OAuth tokens. Common causes:
   270
   271The refresh token itself has expired or been revoked. The account must be removed and re-added via the admin API PKCE flow.
   272
   273The Anthropic token endpoint (`https://console.anthropic.com/v1/oauth/token`) is unreachable. Check outbound network connectivity from the pod. Transient failures are retried on the next refresh cycle (default: every 5 minutes).
   274
   275An account marked `disabled` in the pool health indicates its refresh token is permanently invalid. Remove it and re-authenticate.
   276
   277### Structured Logs
   278
   279All log output is JSON. Key fields to filter on:
   280
   281- `message`: human-readable event description
   282- `request_id`: `req_<uuid>` correlating a proxy request through its lifecycle
   283- `error`: error message when something fails
   284
   285Set log verbosity via the `LOG_LEVEL` environment variable in the deployment. Accepts standard tracing directives: `error`, `warn`, `info`, `debug`, `trace`. Defaults to `info`.
   286
   287## Troubleshooting
   288
   289### Pod Not Starting
   290
   291The startup probe allows up to 60 seconds (30 failures x 2-second period) for the proxy to bind its listener and respond to `/health`. This should happen within seconds under normal conditions. If the startup probe exhausts its budget, Kubernetes restarts the container.
   292
   293Check container logs for configuration errors. Common causes: missing or malformed ConfigMap, invalid `upstream_url`, or `listen_addr` already in use.
   294
   295### Tailnet Not Reachable
   296
   297If the proxy pod is running but not reachable via MagicDNS (`anthropic-oauth-proxy`), the issue is with the Tailscale Operator. Check that the Operator created its proxy StatefulSet from the Ingress resource:
   298
   299```bash
   300kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get statefulset
   301kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get pods -l app=tailscale
   302kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get ingress
   303```
   304
   305Only one Tailscale proxy pod should exist. If there are two (a symptom of dual-proxy conflict from Service annotations), ensure `k8s/service.yaml` has no `tailscale.com/expose` or `tailscale.com/hostname` annotations. The Ingress resource handles all tailnet exposure.
   306
   307### Proxy Returning 502 Bad Gateway
   308
   309The upstream at `https://api.anthropic.com` is unreachable or returning connection errors. Use port-forwarding to test from your workstation:
   310
   311```bash
   312kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy port-forward deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy 8080:8080 &
   313curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://localhost:8080/health
   314```
   315
   316If DNS or TLS fails inside the pod, check that the runtime image has `ca-certificates` installed (it does in the default Dockerfile) and that the pod has outbound internet access.
   317
   318### Proxy Returning 504 Gateway Timeout
   319
   320Upstream did not respond within the configured `timeout_secs` (default: 60s). The proxy automatically retries timeouts up to 2 times (3 total attempts) with 100ms backoff between attempts. If all attempts time out, it returns 504.
   321
   322For sustained 504s, check Anthropic API status. If the API is healthy, consider increasing `timeout_secs` in the ConfigMap for long-running requests.
   323
   324### Proxy Returning 400 Bad Request
   325
   326Either the request body exceeds the 10 MiB hardcoded limit, or the request is malformed. Check the `request_id` in the error response JSON and correlate with proxy logs.
   327
   328### Proxy Returning 429 (OAuth Mode)
   329
   330In OAuth mode, the proxy attempts failover to the next available account when the current account's quota is exhausted (429 with quota message). If all accounts are exhausted, the proxy returns 429 to the client.
   331
   332Check pool status via the health endpoint or admin API to see which accounts are cooling down and when they will become available again. Default cooldown is 2 hours (configurable via `cooldown_secs`).
   333
   334### Pool Exhausted (OAuth Mode)
   335
   336When all accounts are in `cooling_down` or `disabled` state, the proxy returns 429 to all requests. To resolve:
   337
   338- Wait for cooldown timers to expire (check `cooldown_remaining_secs` in pool health)
   339- Add more accounts via the admin API PKCE flow
   340- Remove and re-add disabled accounts (disabled means refresh token is permanently invalid)
   341
   342### High Latency
   343
   344Check `proxy_request_duration_seconds` histogram percentiles. Latency is dominated by upstream response time. The proxy adds negligible overhead (header injection, hop-by-hop stripping, JSON body modification in OAuth mode).
   345
   346If latency correlates with high concurrency, check if `max_connections` (default: 1000) is being hit. The concurrency limiter queues excess requests rather than rejecting them, which manifests as increased latency rather than errors. Health and metrics endpoints are outside the concurrency limit and remain responsive regardless of proxy load.
   347
   348## Graceful Shutdown
   349
   350On SIGTERM (Kubernetes pod termination), the proxy stops accepting new connections and waits for in-flight requests to complete. The `in_flight` atomic counter tracks active requests. The proxy enforces a 5-second `DRAIN_TIMEOUT` starting from when it receives the signal. If in-flight requests complete within 5 seconds, shutdown is clean. If not, the proxy force-exits after 5 seconds regardless of the Kubernetes `terminationGracePeriodSeconds`.
   351
   352The shutdown sequence logged:
   353
   354```text
   355{"message":"received SIGTERM, shutting down",...}
   356{"message":"all in-flight requests drained",...}
   357{"message":"shutdown complete",...}
   358```
   359
   360If requests are still in flight when the 5-second drain timeout expires:
   361
   362```text
   363{"message":"drain timeout exceeded, forcing shutdown","remaining":3,"drain_timeout_secs":5,...}
   364```
   365
   366## Resource Limits
   367
   368Default resource configuration from `k8s/deployment.yaml`:
   369
   370| Container | CPU request | CPU limit | Memory request | Memory limit |
   371|-----------|-------------|-----------|----------------|--------------|
   372| proxy | 50m | 500m | 32Mi | 128Mi |
   373
   374The proxy binary is approximately 5MB and has minimal memory overhead. Increase memory limits if serving large request/response bodies concurrently, though the 10 MiB body size limit provides a natural ceiling.
   375
   376## Header Discovery Maintenance
   377
   378When the Claude CLI updates, the required headers may change. To discover the current header contract:
   379
   380```bash
   381# Install the updated Claude CLI, then sniff traffic
   382mitmdump --set flow_detail=4 -p 8888
   383HTTPS_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:8888 claude --print "hello"
   384```
   385
   386Compare the captured headers against the constants in `services/oauth-proxy/src/provider_impl.rs`. Update the constants and run tests if anything has changed.
   387
