content.content:
1# Anthropic OAuth Proxy  Operational Runbook
     2
     3This runbook covers deployment, operation, monitoring, and troubleshooting of the anthropic-oauth-proxy service. The proxy supports two modes: passthrough (static header injection) and OAuth pool (PKCE auth, token refresh, subscription pooling).
     4
     5## Architecture
     6
     7The pod contains a single container. The Tailscale Operator manages tailnet connectivity via an Ingress resource that creates a proxy StatefulSet routing traffic from the tailnet to the Service ClusterIP.
     8
     9```text
    10                    Tailnet
    11      +----------+         +---------------------+
    12      | Aperture | ------> | Tailscale Operator   |
    13      | (http://ai/)       | proxy (StatefulSet)  |
    14      +----------+         +----------+----------+
    15                                      |
    16                                      v
    17                           +---------------------+       +-----------+
    18                           | anthropic-oauth-proxy| ----> | Anthropic |
    19                           | (single container)   |      | API       |
    20                           +---------------------+       +-----------+
    21                            MagicDNS: anthropic-oauth-proxy
    22                            Proxy: 8080  |  Admin: 9090
    23```
    24
    25In passthrough mode, the proxy injects the `anthropic-beta: oauth-2025-04-20` header and forwards to `https://api.anthropic.com`. In OAuth mode, it manages Bearer tokens from a pool of Claude Max subscriptions, handles automatic token refresh, and injects the full Anthropic header contract (anthropic-beta, anthropic-version, user-agent, system prompt). TLS termination for inbound traffic is handled by the tailnet WireGuard encryption. Outbound TLS to Anthropic uses `reqwest` with `rustls`.
    26
    27## Deployment
    28
    29### Initial Deploy
    30
    31No secrets are required. The container image is public on GHCR (anonymous pull). Tailnet authentication is handled by the Tailscale Operator.
    32
    33```bash
    34kubectl apply -k k8s/
    35```
    36
    37This creates the namespace, ServiceAccount, ConfigMap, PVC, Deployment, Services (proxy + admin), and Ingress. The Tailscale Operator detects the Ingress and creates a StatefulSet to proxy from the tailnet to the ClusterIP.
    38
    39### Verify Deployment
    40
    41```bash
    42kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get pods
    43kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy logs deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
    44```
    45
    46A healthy startup sequence in the logs (JSON structured):
    47
    48```text
    49{"message":"starting anthropic-oauth-proxy",...}
    50{"message":"loading configuration","path":"/etc/anthropic-oauth-proxy/config.toml",...}
    51{"message":"configuration loaded","listen_addr":"0.0.0.0:8080",...}
    52{"message":"state: Starting",...}
    53{"message":"state: Running  accepting requests","addr":"0.0.0.0:8080",...}
    54```
    55
    56Verify the Tailscale Operator created its proxy StatefulSet:
    57
    58```bash
    59kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get statefulset
    60```
    61
    62### End-to-End Test
    63
    64Test the full request path over the tailnet. Requests must use HTTPS against the Tailscale FQDN (not the short MagicDNS name, which lacks a valid TLS cert for curl). No credentials are needed in the request  the proxy injects everything.
    65
    66```bash
    67curl -s -X POST "https://anthropic-oauth-proxy.tailfb3ea.ts.net/v1/messages" \
    68  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
    69  -d '{
    70    "model": "claude-haiku-4-5-20251001",
    71    "max_tokens": 64,
    72    "messages": [{"role": "user", "content": "Say hello in exactly 5 words."}]
    73  }' | jq .
    74```
    75
    76A successful response contains `"type": "message"` with a `content` array and `usage` block. The request path is:
    77
    78```text
    79curl  tailnet (WireGuard)  Tailscale Ingress (TLS termination)
    80      Service (ClusterIP :80)  proxy (:8080, OAuth token injection)
    81      api.anthropic.com  200 OK
    82```
    83
    84Common failures at this stage:
    85
    86| Symptom | Cause |
    87|---------|-------|
    88| Connection refused on port 80 | Using `http://` instead of `https://`, or using the short MagicDNS name without port 443 |
    89| TLS handshake error | Using the short name `anthropic-oauth-proxy` instead of the FQDN `anthropic-oauth-proxy.tailfb3ea.ts.net` |
    90| 400 from Cloudflare | Request reached Anthropic but was malformed  check proxy logs for the request_id |
    91| 401 Unauthorized | Token expired or invalid  check `curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/pool \| jq .` (requires admin port-forward) |
    92| 503 Service Unavailable | Pool exhausted  no available accounts |
    93
    94### Switching to OAuth Mode
    95
    96To switch from passthrough to OAuth mode, update the ConfigMap to uncomment the `[oauth]` and `[admin]` sections (and optionally remove `[[headers]]`  `[oauth]` takes precedence automatically). Then restart the deployment:
    97
    98```bash
    99kubectl apply -k k8s/
   100kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout restart deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
   101```
   102
   103The proxy starts in OAuth mode with an empty pool. Add accounts via the admin API (see below).
   104
   105### Updating Configuration
   106
   107The ConfigMap at `k8s/configmap.yaml` holds the TOML configuration. After editing:
   108
   109```bash
   110kubectl apply -k k8s/
   111kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout restart deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
   112```
   113
   114### Rollback
   115
   116If a deployment introduces issues, roll back to the previous revision:
   117
   118```bash
   119kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout undo deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
   120kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout status deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
   121```
   122
   123Kubernetes retains the previous ReplicaSet by default, so `rollout undo` restores both the container image and the ConfigMap hash from the prior revision. For rollbacks beyond one revision, use `rollout undo --to-revision=<N>` where `N` is from `rollout history`.
   124
   125## OAuth Account Management
   126
   127Accounts are managed via the admin API on port 9090. The admin port is not exposed via Ingress  access it through `kubectl port-forward`.
   128
   129### Accessing the Admin API
   130
   131```bash
   132kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy port-forward deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy 9090:9090
   133```
   134
   135All admin commands below assume port-forwarding is active.
   136
   137### Adding an Account (PKCE Flow)
   138
   139Step 1  Initiate the OAuth flow:
   140
   141```bash
   142curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts/init-oauth | jq .
   143```
   144
   145Response:
   146
   147```json
   148{
   149  "authorization_url": "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize?client_id=...&code_challenge=...",
   150  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
   151  "instructions": "Open the URL in a browser, authorize, then paste the code to complete-oauth"
   152}
   153```
   154
   155Step 2  Open the `authorization_url` in a browser and authorize with the Claude Max account. After authorization, the browser redirects to a page showing a `code#state` value.
   156
   157Step 3  Complete the flow:
   158
   159```bash
   160curl -s -X POST http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts/complete-oauth \
   161  -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
   162  -d '{"account_id": "claude-max-1739059200", "code": "AUTH_CODE#STATE"}' | jq .
   163```
   164
   165The PKCE state expires after 10 minutes. If Step 3 is not completed in time, start over from Step 1.
   166
   167### Adding an Account (Keychain Extraction)
   168
   169If the PKCE consent flow fails (see Known Issues), credentials can be extracted from a local Claude Code installation and loaded directly.
   170
   171Step 1  Extract tokens from the macOS keychain (tokens are not printed):
   172
   173```bash
   174CREDS=$(security find-generic-password -s "Claude Code-credentials" -a "$(whoami)" -w)
   175echo "$CREDS" | python3 -c "
   176import json, sys
   177data = json.load(sys.stdin)
   178oauth = data['claudeAiOauth']
   179print(json.dumps({
   180    'claude-max-local': {
   181        'type': 'oauth',
   182        'refresh': oauth['refreshToken'],
   183        'access': oauth['accessToken'],
   184        'expires': oauth['expiresAt']
   185    }
   186}, indent=2))
   187" > /tmp/credentials.json
   188```
   189
   190Step 2  Copy the credential file into the pod:
   191
   192```bash
   193POD=$(kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get pods -l app=anthropic-oauth-proxy -o name | head -1)
   194kubectl cp /tmp/credentials.json anthropic-oauth-proxy/${POD#pod/}:/data/credentials.json -c proxy
   195```
   196
   197Step 3  Restart the pod to load the new credentials:
   198
   199```bash
   200kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy rollout restart deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy
   201```
   202
   203Step 4  Verify the account loaded:
   204
   205```bash
   206curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/pool | jq .
   207```
   208
   209Clean up the local temp file after confirming:
   210
   211```bash
   212rm -f /tmp/credentials.json
   213```
   214
   215The keychain entry name varies by platform. On macOS, Claude Code stores credentials under service `Claude Code-credentials`. The `claudeAiOauth` key contains the tokens for claude.ai OAuth (Max/Pro subscriptions). The `expiresAt` field is already in unix milliseconds, matching the gateway's `expires` field directly.
   216
   217### Listing Accounts
   218
   219```bash
   220curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts | jq .
   221```
   222
   223Response includes account IDs and status (available, cooling_down, disabled). Tokens are never exposed.
   224
   225### Removing an Account
   226
   227```bash
   228curl -s -X DELETE http://localhost:9090/admin/accounts/claude-max-1739059200 | jq .
   229```
   230
   231Removes the account from the pool and credential store. Idempotent.
   232
   233### Pool Status
   234
   235```bash
   236curl -s http://localhost:9090/admin/pool | jq .
   237```
   238
   239Returns per-account status, cooldown timers, and overall pool health.
   240
   241### Credential Persistence
   242
   243OAuth credentials are stored in `/data/credentials.json` on a PersistentVolumeClaim. Pod restarts preserve tokens  no need to re-authenticate accounts after restart.
   244
   245The single-replica constraint exists because PKCE state is held in-memory. Running multiple pods would split the init/complete flow across pods. This does not affect credential persistence (PVC survives pod restarts).
   246
   247## Endpoints
   248
   249| Path | Port | Purpose | Response |
   250|------|------|---------|----------|
   251| `GET /health` | 8080 | Startup, liveness, readiness probe | JSON with status, uptime, pool status |
   252| `GET /metrics` | 8080 | Prometheus scrape target | Text exposition format |
   253| `* /*` | 8080 | Proxy fallback | Forwards to upstream |
   254| `GET /admin/accounts` | 9090 | List accounts | JSON account list |
   255| `POST /admin/accounts/init-oauth` | 9090 | Start PKCE flow | JSON with auth URL |
   256| `POST /admin/accounts/complete-oauth` | 9090 | Exchange code | JSON confirmation |
   257| `DELETE /admin/accounts/{id}` | 9090 | Remove account | JSON confirmation |
   258| `GET /admin/pool` | 9090 | Pool health summary | JSON pool status |
   259
   260### Health Endpoint Response
   261
   262The health endpoint always returns HTTP 200 when the listener is bound. The `status` field indicates pool health.
   263
   264Passthrough mode:
   265
   266```json
   267{
   268  "status": "healthy",
   269  "mode": "passthrough",
   270  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   271  "requests_served": 12345,
   272  "errors_total": 0
   273}
   274```
   275
   276OAuth mode:
   277
   278```json
   279{
   280  "status": "degraded",
   281  "mode": "anthropic",
   282  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   283  "requests_served": 12345,
   284  "errors_total": 0,
   285  "pool": {
   286    "accounts_total": 3,
   287    "accounts_available": 2,
   288    "accounts_cooling": 1,
   289    "accounts_disabled": 0,
   290    "accounts": [
   291      { "id": "claude-max-1", "status": "available" },
   292      { "id": "claude-max-2", "status": "cooling_down", "cooldown_remaining_secs": 3600 },
   293      { "id": "claude-max-3", "status": "available" }
   294    ]
   295  }
   296}
   297```
   298
   299Status mapping: all available = `healthy`, some cooling/disabled = `degraded`, all cooling/disabled = `unhealthy`.
   300
   301## Monitoring
   302
   303### Prometheus Metrics
   304
   305Scrape `GET /metrics` on port 8080. Metrics emitted:
   306
   307`proxy_requests_total` (counter) with labels `status` and `method` tracks completed proxy requests. Use this for request rate and error rate calculations.
   308
   309`proxy_request_duration_seconds` (histogram) with label `status` and bucket boundaries from 5ms to 60s. Use `histogram_quantile()` in PromQL to compute latency percentiles (p50, p90, p99) from the histogram buckets at query time.
   310
   311`proxy_upstream_errors_total` (counter) with label `error_type` tracks upstream failures. Error types: `timeout` (upstream did not respond within `timeout_secs`), `connection` (TCP connection to upstream failed), `invalid_request` (request body exceeded 10 MiB limit or malformed request).
   312
   313OAuth mode adds four additional metrics:
   314
   315`pool_account_status` (gauge) with labels `account_id` and `status`. Tracks the current state of each account in the pool (available, cooling_down, disabled).
   316
   317`pool_failovers_total` (counter) with labels `from_account` and `reason`. Incremented when the proxy fails over from one account to the next due to quota exhaustion or permanent error.
   318
   319`pool_token_refreshes_total` (counter) with labels `account_id` and `result`. Tracks token refresh attempts (success or failure).
   320
   321`pool_quota_exhaustions_total` (counter) with label `account_id`. Incremented when an account hits its usage quota (429 with quota message).
   322
   323### Key Alerts
   324
   325Alert on sustained upstream errors:
   326
   327```text
   328rate(proxy_upstream_errors_total[5m]) > 0.1
   329```
   330
   331Alert on p99 latency approaching the 60s timeout. The `sum by (le)` aggregation is required because the histogram carries a `status` label:
   332
   333```text
   334histogram_quantile(0.99, sum by (le) (rate(proxy_request_duration_seconds_bucket[5m]))) > 30
   335```
   336
   337Alert when all pool accounts are exhausted (OAuth mode). This fires when no accounts are available:
   338
   339```text
   340sum(pool_account_status{status="available"}) == 0
   341```
   342
   343Alert on high failover rate indicating quota pressure across accounts:
   344
   345```text
   346rate(pool_failovers_total[5m]) > 0.05
   347```
   348
   349### Token Refresh Troubleshooting
   350
   351If `pool_token_refreshes_total{result="failure"}` is incrementing, accounts are failing to refresh their OAuth tokens. Common causes:
   352
   353The refresh token itself has expired or been revoked. The account must be removed and re-added via the admin API PKCE flow.
   354
   355The Anthropic token endpoint (`https://console.anthropic.com/v1/oauth/token`) is unreachable. Check outbound network connectivity from the pod. Transient failures are retried on the next refresh cycle (default: every 5 minutes).
   356
   357An account marked `disabled` in the pool health indicates its refresh token is permanently invalid. Remove it and re-authenticate.
   358
   359### Structured Logs
   360
   361All log output is JSON. Key fields to filter on:
   362
   363- `message`: human-readable event description
   364- `request_id`: `req_<uuid>` correlating a proxy request through its lifecycle
   365- `error`: error message when something fails
   366
   367Set log verbosity via the `LOG_LEVEL` environment variable in the deployment. Accepts standard tracing directives: `error`, `warn`, `info`, `debug`, `trace`. Defaults to `info`.
   368
   369## Troubleshooting
   370
   371### Pod Not Starting
   372
   373The startup probe allows up to 60 seconds (30 failures x 2-second period) for the proxy to bind its listener and respond to `/health`. This should happen within seconds under normal conditions. If the startup probe exhausts its budget, Kubernetes restarts the container.
   374
   375Check container logs for configuration errors. Common causes: missing or malformed ConfigMap, invalid `upstream_url`, or `listen_addr` already in use.
   376
   377### Tailnet Not Reachable
   378
   379If the proxy pod is running but not reachable via MagicDNS (`anthropic-oauth-proxy`), the issue is with the Tailscale Operator. Check that the Operator created its proxy StatefulSet from the Ingress resource:
   380
   381```bash
   382kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get statefulset
   383kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get pods -l app=tailscale
   384kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy get ingress
   385```
   386
   387Only one Tailscale proxy pod should exist. If there are two (a symptom of dual-proxy conflict from Service annotations), ensure `k8s/service.yaml` has no `tailscale.com/expose` or `tailscale.com/hostname` annotations. The Ingress resource handles all tailnet exposure.
   388
   389### Proxy Returning 502 Bad Gateway
   390
   391The upstream at `https://api.anthropic.com` is unreachable or returning connection errors. Use port-forwarding to test from your workstation:
   392
   393```bash
   394kubectl -n anthropic-oauth-proxy port-forward deployment/anthropic-oauth-proxy 8080:8080 &
   395curl -s -o /dev/null -w '%{http_code}' http://localhost:8080/health
   396```
   397
   398If DNS or TLS fails inside the pod, check that the runtime image has `ca-certificates` installed (it does in the default Dockerfile) and that the pod has outbound internet access.
   399
   400### Proxy Returning 504 Gateway Timeout
   401
   402Upstream did not respond within the configured `timeout_secs` (default: 60s). The proxy automatically retries timeouts up to 2 times (3 total attempts) with 100ms backoff between attempts. If all attempts time out, it returns 504.
   403
   404For sustained 504s, check Anthropic API status. If the API is healthy, consider increasing `timeout_secs` in the ConfigMap for long-running requests.
   405
   406### Proxy Returning 400 Bad Request
   407
   408Either the request body exceeds the 10 MiB hardcoded limit, or the request is malformed. Check the `request_id` in the error response JSON and correlate with proxy logs.
   409
   410### Proxy Returning 429 (OAuth Mode)
   411
   412In OAuth mode, the proxy attempts failover to the next available account when the current account's quota is exhausted (429 with quota message). If all accounts are exhausted, the proxy returns 429 to the client.
   413
   414Check pool status via the health endpoint or admin API to see which accounts are cooling down and when they will become available again. Default cooldown is 2 hours (configurable via `cooldown_secs`).
   415
   416### Pool Exhausted (OAuth Mode)
   417
   418When all accounts are in `cooling_down` or `disabled` state, the proxy returns 429 to all requests. To resolve:
   419
   420- Wait for cooldown timers to expire (check `cooldown_remaining_secs` in pool health)
   421- Add more accounts via the admin API PKCE flow
   422- Remove and re-add disabled accounts (disabled means refresh token is permanently invalid)
   423
   424### High Latency
   425
   426Check `proxy_request_duration_seconds` histogram percentiles. Latency is dominated by upstream response time. The proxy adds negligible overhead (header injection, hop-by-hop stripping, JSON body modification in OAuth mode).
   427
   428If latency correlates with high concurrency, check if `max_connections` (default: 1000) is being hit. The concurrency limiter queues excess requests rather than rejecting them, which manifests as increased latency rather than errors. Health and metrics endpoints are outside the concurrency limit and remain responsive regardless of proxy load.
   429
   430## Graceful Shutdown
   431
   432On SIGTERM (Kubernetes pod termination), the proxy stops accepting new connections and waits for in-flight requests to complete. The `in_flight` atomic counter tracks active requests. The proxy enforces a 5-second `DRAIN_TIMEOUT` starting from when it receives the signal. If in-flight requests complete within 5 seconds, shutdown is clean. If not, the proxy force-exits after 5 seconds regardless of the Kubernetes `terminationGracePeriodSeconds`.
   433
   434The shutdown sequence logged:
   435
   436```text
   437{"message":"received SIGTERM, shutting down",...}
   438{"message":"all in-flight requests drained",...}
   439{"message":"shutdown complete",...}
   440```
   441
   442If requests are still in flight when the 5-second drain timeout expires:
   443
   444```text
   445{"message":"drain timeout exceeded, forcing shutdown","remaining":3,"drain_timeout_secs":5,...}
   446```
   447
   448## Resource Limits
   449
   450Default resource configuration from `k8s/deployment.yaml`:
   451
   452| Container | CPU request | CPU limit | Memory request | Memory limit |
   453|-----------|-------------|-----------|----------------|--------------|
   454| proxy | 50m | 500m | 32Mi | 128Mi |
   455
   456The proxy binary is approximately 5MB and has minimal memory overhead. Increase memory limits if serving large request/response bodies concurrently, though the 10 MiB body size limit provides a natural ceiling.
   457
   458## Header Discovery Maintenance
   459
   460When the Claude CLI updates, the required headers may change. To discover the current header contract:
   461
   462```bash
   463# Install the updated Claude CLI, then sniff traffic
   464mitmdump --set flow_detail=4 -p 8888
   465HTTPS_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:8888 claude --print "hello"
   466```
   467
   468Compare the captured headers against the constants in `services/oauth-proxy/src/provider_impl.rs`. Update the constants and run tests if anything has changed.
   469
   470## Known Issues
   471
   472### OAuth Consent Page "Invalid request format"
   473
   474The PKCE flow's `init-oauth` endpoint generates an authorization URL for `claude.ai/oauth/authorize`. The consent page loads correctly (shows "Claude Code would like to connect to your Claude chat account" with the expected scopes), but clicking "Authorize" fails with "Invalid request format" in the browser's React Query mutation. This occurs in both normal and incognito browser sessions.
   475
   476The root cause is unclear. The gateway uses the same client ID, redirect URI, and PKCE parameters as the Claude Code CLI. Possible factors:
   477
   478- Anthropic may have added server-side validation that rejects the authorization grant for sessions not initiated by the official Claude Code CLI binary.
   479- The gateway requests scopes `user:profile user:inference user:sessions:claude_code`, while the Claude Code CLI's keychain tokens include an additional `user:mcp_servers` scope. The consent page may require this scope for approval to succeed.
   480- Anthropic has publicly stated they block third-party tools from using Claude Code OAuth tokens. The consent page rejection may be part of this enforcement.
   481
   482Workaround: Use the keychain extraction method (see "Adding an Account  Keychain Extraction" above) to load tokens from an existing Claude Code installation. The extracted tokens work correctly for API requests through the gateway.
   483
   484### Credential File Missing `type` Field
   485
   486The credential file requires a `type` field (value: `"oauth"`) on every credential entry. Omitting it causes a fatal parse error on startup (`missing field 'type'`), putting the pod into CrashLoopBackOff. If this happens, the PVC retains the bad file across restarts.
   487
   488Recovery: scale the deployment to 0 (disable ArgoCD auto-sync first if enabled), run a temporary pod mounting the PVC, fix the file, then restore. See the field reference in `specs/anthropic-oauth-gateway.md` for the required format.
   489

content.content:
1# Spec: Anthropic OAuth Gateway
     2
     3**Status:** Complete
     4**Created:** 2026-02-09
     5**Author:** Brent + Cowork
     6**Supersedes:** `oauth-proxy.md` (header injector  full OAuth gateway)
     7
     8---
     9
    10## Overview
    11
    12Evolve the anthropic-oauth-proxy from a static header injector into a full OAuth 2.0 gateway with subscription pooling. The proxy currently passes through client-provided `Authorization` headers and injects `anthropic-beta: oauth-2025-04-20`. The target state manages its own OAuth credentials: PKCE authentication flow, automatic token refresh, round-robin subscription pooling with quota failover, and the full Anthropic header contract.
    13
    14Clients on the tailnet send unauthenticated requests. The gateway handles everything.
    15
    16**Pins:**
    17
    18| Reference | What it provides |
    19|-----------|-----------------|
    20| Loom `specs/claude-subscription-auth.md` | OAuth 2.0 PKCE flow, token exchange/refresh, credential storage, header contract |
    21| Loom `specs/anthropic-oauth-pool.md` | Subscription pooling, round-robin failover, quota detection, health reporting |
    22| Loom `specs/anthropic-max-pool-management.md` | Admin API patterns, proactive token refresh, account lifecycle |
    23| Aperture by Tailscale | Multi-provider gateway architecture, Tailscale identity, model-based routing |
    24
    25**Design Principles (carried forward):**
    26
    27| Principle | Implementation |
    28|-----------|----------------|
    29| Single responsibility | One binary, one provider (Anthropic) |
    30| Provider trait | Multi-provider interface designed in, only Anthropic implemented |
    31| Tailnet-native | MagicDNS identity via Tailscale Operator |
    32| Pure state machines | Auth state, pool state, service lifecycle  all explicit |
    33| Zero client credentials | Clients send bare requests; gateway injects everything |
    34
    35---
    36
    37## Architecture
    38
    39```text
    40
    41                              Tailnet                                      
    42                                                                           
    43              
    44   Aperture   Tailscale     anthropic-oauth-proxy         
    45   (http://ai/)     Operator                                         
    46         Ingress                
    47                               OAuth Pool             
    48                                         
    49  ForgeFlare     Max1   Max2 ...     
    50                                                  
    51                                                     
    52                                  
    53   Claude                                  
    54   Code                                                              
    55                                  
    56                                            Header Injection          
    57                                            + System Prompt Gate      
    58                                            + Token Refresh           
    59                                              
    60                                          
    61                                                                         
    62                                                                         
    63                                              api.anthropic.com           
    64
    65```
    66
    67MagicDNS hostname remains `anthropic-oauth-proxy`. Same Tailscale Ingress, same K8s footprint. Binary name unchanged. The upgrade is internal.
    68
    69---
    70
    71## Auth Modes
    72
    73The gateway supports two mutually exclusive auth modes, determined at startup:
    74
    75| Mode | Source | Behavior |
    76|------|--------|----------|
    77| **Passthrough** (current) | `[headers]` config with no `[oauth]` section | Inject static headers, pass through client Authorization. Backward compatible. |
    78| **OAuth Pool** | `[oauth]` section present | Manage credentials, inject Bearer token + full header contract. Client Authorization ignored. |
    79
    80This preserves backward compatibility. Existing deployments with `[[headers]]` config continue to work. Adding an `[oauth]` section activates the new behavior.
    81
    82---
    83
    84## Multi-Provider Interface
    85
    86The gateway is Anthropic-only but the provider abstraction is designed for future extension.
    87
    88### Provider Trait
    89
    90```rust
    91/// Trait for LLM provider authentication and request preparation.
    92/// Anthropic is the only implementation. Designed for future providers
    93/// (OpenAI, Google) without breaking changes.
    94pub trait Provider: Send + Sync {
    95    /// Provider identifier (e.g., "anthropic")
    96    fn id(&self) -> &str;
    97
    98    /// Prepare an outbound request: inject auth headers, modify body if needed.
    99    /// Called once per proxy attempt (not per retry).
   100    async fn prepare_request(
   101        &self,
   102        request: &mut RequestBuilder,
   103        body: &mut serde_json::Value,
   104    ) -> Result<(), ProviderError>;
   105
   106    /// Classify an upstream error for failover decisions.
   107    fn classify_error(&self, status: u16, body: &str) -> ErrorClassification;
   108
   109    /// Report an error back to the provider (e.g., mark account as cooling).
   110    async fn report_error(
   111        &self,
   112        classification: ErrorClassification,
   113    ) -> Result<(), ProviderError>;
   114
   115    /// Health status for the /health endpoint.
   116    async fn health(&self) -> ProviderHealth;
   117}
   118```
   119
   120### Error Classification
   121
   122```rust
   123#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy)]
   124pub enum ErrorClassification {
   125    /// Transient error, retry on same account (via existing retry loop)
   126    Transient,
   127    /// Quota exhausted, failover to next account in pool
   128    QuotaExceeded,
   129    /// Permanent error (bad credentials), disable account
   130    Permanent,
   131}
   132```
   133
   134---
   135
   136## OAuth Implementation
   137
   138### Constants
   139
   140```rust
   141/// Anthropic's public OAuth client ID (same as Claude CLI)
   142pub const ANTHROPIC_CLIENT_ID: &str = "9d1c250a-e61b-44d9-88ed-5944d1962f5e";
   143
   144/// OAuth redirect URI
   145pub const REDIRECT_URI: &str = "https://console.anthropic.com/oauth/code/callback";
   146
   147/// Token endpoint
   148pub const TOKEN_ENDPOINT: &str = "https://console.anthropic.com/v1/oauth/token";
   149
   150/// Authorization endpoint (Pro/Max subscriptions)
   151pub const AUTHORIZE_ENDPOINT: &str = "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize";
   152
   153/// OAuth scopes (user:sessions:claude_code required for Sonnet/Opus)
   154/// Note: org:create_api_key is NOT included  that's for Console OAuth (API key creation),
   155/// which is out of scope. This gateway only does Max (claude.ai) authorization.
   156pub const SCOPES: &str = "user:profile user:inference user:sessions:claude_code";
   157
   158/// Required system prompt prefix for Opus/Sonnet access
   159pub const REQUIRED_SYSTEM_PROMPT_PREFIX: &str =
   160    "You are Claude Code, Anthropic's official CLI for Claude.";
   161```
   162
   163### PKCE Flow
   164
   165Standard OAuth 2.0 with PKCE (RFC 7636). No client secret (public client).
   166
   167```text
   168Admin CLI                    Gateway                     claude.ai
   169                                                           
   170      add-account                                          
   171                                
   172                                 Generate PKCE pair        
   173                                 (verifier + S256 challenge)
   174      authorization_url                                    
   175                                
   176                                                           
   177      Open browser 
   178                                                           
   179      User authorizes                                      
   180    
   181                                                           
   182      Paste code#{state}                                   
   183                                
   184                                 POST /v1/oauth/token      
   185                               
   186                                 {access, refresh, expires}
   187                               
   188                                                           
   189                                 Store credentials         
   190                                 Add to pool (hot-reload)  
   191      Account added                                        
   192                                
   193```
   194
   195### Credential Storage
   196
   197JSON file on disk, keyed by account ID. Mounted as a PersistentVolume in K8s.
   198
   199#### Field Reference
   200
   201| Field | Type | Required | Description |
   202|-------|------|----------|-------------|
   203| `type` | string | yes | Always `"oauth"`. Discriminator for future credential types. Deserialized via `#[serde(rename = "type")]`. |
   204| `refresh` | string | yes | Refresh token for obtaining new access tokens. Prefix: `sk-ant-ort*`. Used by background refresh and request-time refresh. |
   205| `access` | string | yes | Current Bearer token for API calls. Prefix: `sk-ant-oat*`. Injected as `Authorization: Bearer {access}`. |
   206| `expires` | u64 | yes | Absolute expiration as unix timestamp in **milliseconds**. Computed from `TokenResponse.expires_in` (seconds delta) + current time at storage. |
   207
   208The account ID key (e.g., `claude-max-1739059200`) is an opaque string. The admin API generates IDs in the format `claude-max-{unix_timestamp}`. Manually created entries can use any unique string.
   209
   210#### Example `credentials.json`
   211
   212```json
   213{
   214  "claude-max-1739059200": {
   215    "type": "oauth",
   216    "refresh": "sk-ant-ort01-example...",
   217    "access": "sk-ant-oat01-example...",
   218    "expires": 1739073600000
   219  },
   220  "claude-max-1739145600": {
   221    "type": "oauth",
   222    "refresh": "sk-ant-ort01-example...",
   223    "access": "sk-ant-oat01-example...",
   224    "expires": 1739160000000
   225  }
   226}
   227```
   228
   229File permissions: `0600`, owned by container UID 1000 (non-root). Never exposed via API. Health endpoint shows account IDs and status only.
   230
   231Missing or empty file (`{}`) is a valid cold start  the pool reports `unhealthy` until accounts are added. Omitting the `type` field causes a fatal parse error on startup.
   232
   233**Atomic writes:** Credential file updates use write-to-temp + atomic rename to prevent corruption on crash mid-write. All writes acquire an in-memory `Mutex` to prevent concurrent modification from request-time refresh and background refresh tasks.
   234
   235**Cold start:** If credential file does not exist, create it as `{}`. Pool starts with zero accounts, health reports `unhealthy` with `accounts_total: 0`. First request returns 503 until an account is added via admin API.
   236
   237---
   238
   239## Subscription Pool
   240
   241### Account State Machine
   242
   243```rust
   244#[derive(Debug, Clone, Copy, PartialEq, Eq)]
   245pub enum AccountStatus {
   246    /// Ready to serve requests
   247    Available,
   248    /// Hit 5-hour quota, cooling down
   249    CoolingDown { until: Instant },
   250    /// Permanently failed (invalid credentials, revoked token)
   251    Disabled,
   252}
   253```
   254
   255### State Transitions
   256
   257| Current | Trigger | New State | Action |
   258|---------|---------|-----------|--------|
   259| `Available` | Request succeeds | `Available` | None |
   260| `Available` | 429 + quota message | `CoolingDown` | Log, failover to next |
   261| `Available` | 401/403 | `Disabled` | Log error, failover |
   262| `Available` | Transient error | `Available` | Retry (existing retry loop) |
   263| `CoolingDown` | Cooldown expired | `Available` | Log recovery |
   264| `CoolingDown` | Token refresh fails | `Disabled` | Log error |
   265| `Disabled` | Admin removes | (removed) | Persist credential file |
   266
   267State transitions apply uniformly: a 401/403 from token refresh (request-time or background) transitions the account to `Disabled` regardless of previous state. `CoolingDown` accounts that fail background refresh go directly to `Disabled`.
   268
   269### Account Selection (Round-Robin)
   270
   2711. Start from `next_index`
   2722. Scan N accounts for `Available` status
   2733. Check `CoolingDown` accounts  if cooldown expired, transition to `Available`
   2744. Select first `Available`, advance `next_index`
   2755. If none available  503 Service Unavailable:
   276```json
   277{
   278  "error": {
   279    "type": "pool_exhausted",
   280    "message": "All accounts exhausted",
   281    "pool": {
   282      "accounts_total": 2,
   283      "accounts_available": 0,
   284      "accounts_cooling": 2,
   285      "accounts_disabled": 0
   286    }
   287  }
   288}
   289```
   290
   291### Quota Detection
   292
   293Not all 429s are quota exhaustion. The classifier inspects the error message body:
   294
   295| HTTP Status | Message Pattern | Classification |
   296|-------------|----------------|----------------|
   297| 429 | Contains "5-hour", "5 hour", "rolling window", "usage limit for your plan", "subscription usage limit" | `QuotaExceeded` |
   298| 429 | Other rate limit messages | `Transient` |
   299| 401, 403 | Any | `Permanent` |
   300| 408, 500, 502, 503, 504 | Any | `Transient` |
   301
   302### Cooldown
   303
   304Default: 2 hours (configurable via `cooldown_secs`). Conservative  the actual 5-hour window is rolling, so 2h is a safe recovery margin.
   305
   306---
   307
   308## Request Pipeline
   309
   310The gateway modifies both headers and body before forwarding.
   311
   312### Header Injection (OAuth Mode)
   313
   314| Header | Value | Notes |
   315|--------|-------|-------|
   316| `Authorization` | `Bearer {access_token}` | From selected pool account. Client-provided Authorization is **ignored** (stripped before injection). |
   317| `anthropic-beta` | `oauth-2025-04-20,interleaved-thinking-2025-05-14,context-management-2025-06-27` | Must include `oauth-2025-04-20` |
   318| `anthropic-dangerous-direct-browser-access` | `true` | Required for OAuth |
   319| `user-agent` | `claude-cli/2.0.76 (external, sdk-cli)` | Must match Claude CLI format |
   320| `anthropic-version` | `2023-06-01` | API version |
   321
   322Client-provided `anthropic-beta` values are merged (deduplicated) with the required set.
   323
   324### System Prompt Prefix Injection
   325
   326For Opus and Sonnet models, the system prompt **must** start with the exact phrase:
   327
   328```text
   329You are Claude Code, Anthropic's official CLI for Claude.
   330```
   331
   332The gateway inspects the request body:
   333
   334| Condition | Action |
   335|-----------|--------|
   336| No `system` field | Inject `system` with required prefix |
   337| `system` field exists, missing prefix | Prepend prefix + `" "` + existing content |
   338| `system` field exists, has prefix | No modification |
   339| Model is Haiku | No modification (prefix not required) |
   340
   341```rust
   342fn inject_system_prompt(body: &mut serde_json::Value, model: &str) {
   343    // Haiku doesn't need the prefix
   344    if model.contains("haiku") {
   345        return;
   346    }
   347
   348    let prefix = REQUIRED_SYSTEM_PROMPT_PREFIX;
   349
   350    match body.get_mut("system") {
   351        None => {
   352            body["system"] = serde_json::Value::String(prefix.to_string());
   353        }
   354        Some(system) => {
   355            if let Some(s) = system.as_str() {
   356                if !s.starts_with(prefix) {
   357                    *system = serde_json::Value::String(
   358                        format!("{} {}", prefix, s)
   359                    );
   360                }
   361            }
   362        }
   363    }
   364}
   365```
   366
   367### Model Extraction
   368
   369The gateway extracts the model name from the request body to determine:
   370
   3711. Whether system prompt injection is needed (non-Haiku)
   3722. Logging and metrics labels
   373
   374```rust
   375fn extract_model(body: &serde_json::Value) -> Option<&str> {
   376    body.get("model").and_then(|v| v.as_str())
   377}
   378```
   379
   380### Body Handling Path
   381
   382The current proxy forwards request bodies as opaque bytes. OAuth mode requires body modification (system prompt injection), which means `bytes  serde_json::Value  modify  serialize  forward`. This is the riskiest refactor  it touches the hot path and introduces a JSON round-trip that could alter field ordering, whitespace, or unicode escapes.
   383
   384| Mode | Body Path | Cost |
   385|------|-----------|------|
   386| Passthrough | Opaque bytes forwarded unchanged | Zero overhead (existing behavior) |
   387| OAuth | Deserialize  modify  serialize | JSON round-trip on every request |
   388
   389Design choice: **always deserialize in OAuth mode.** The latency of an Anthropic API call (seconds) dwarfs JSON serde time (microseconds). Optimizing with string-scan peeking adds complexity for negligible gain at this scale.
   390
   391The `Provider` trait receives `&mut serde_json::Value` so providers that don't need body modification (future OpenAI provider) can simply no-op. The deserialization happens once in `proxy.rs` before calling `provider.prepare_request()`, only when the provider is in OAuth mode.
   392
   393---
   394
   395## Token Refresh
   396
   397### Auto-Refresh on Request
   398
   399Before each proxied request, the gateway checks the selected account's token expiration:
   400
   401| Condition | Action |
   402|-----------|--------|
   403| Token valid (>60s remaining) | Use current access token |
   404| Token expiring (<60s) or expired | Refresh via `POST /v1/oauth/token` with `grant_type=refresh_token` |
   405| Refresh succeeds | Update in-memory + persist to credential file |
   406| Refresh fails | Mark account `Disabled`, failover to next |
   407
   408### Proactive Background Refresh
   409
   410A background tokio task runs independently of request flow:
   411
   412| Parameter | Default | Config Key |
   413|-----------|---------|------------|
   414| Check interval | 5 minutes | `refresh_interval_secs` |
   415| Refresh threshold | 15 minutes | `refresh_threshold_secs` |
   416
   417The task iterates all accounts, refreshing any token expiring within the threshold. This prevents mid-request refresh latency under normal operation.
   418
   419---
   420
   421## Configuration
   422
   423### File Format (TOML)
   424
   425```toml
   426# anthropic-oauth-proxy.toml
   427
   428[proxy]
   429listen_addr = "0.0.0.0:8080"
   430upstream_url = "https://api.anthropic.com"
   431timeout_secs = 60
   432max_connections = 1000
   433
   434# OAuth pool configuration (presence activates OAuth mode)
   435[oauth]
   436credential_file = "/data/credentials.json"
   437cooldown_secs = 7200          # 2 hours
   438refresh_interval_secs = 300   # 5 minutes
   439refresh_threshold_secs = 900  # 15 minutes
   440
   441# Static accounts to load from credential file at startup
   442# New accounts can be added at runtime via admin API
   443providers = ["claude-max-1", "claude-max-2"]
   444
   445# Admin API (for account management)
   446[admin]
   447enabled = true
   448listen_addr = "0.0.0.0:9090"  # Separate port, not exposed via Ingress
   449```
   450
   451When `[oauth]` is absent, the gateway falls back to passthrough mode using `[[headers]]` (backward compatible with current config). If both `[oauth]` and `[[headers]]` are present, `[oauth]` takes precedence and `[[headers]]` is ignored.
   452
   453### Environment Variables
   454
   455| Variable | Description |
   456|----------|-------------|
   457| `CONFIG_PATH` | Config file path (existing) |
   458| `LOG_LEVEL` | Logging verbosity (existing) |
   459| `CREDENTIAL_FILE` | Override credential file path |
   460
   461---
   462
   463## Admin API
   464
   465Separate listener on a non-Ingress port. Accessed via `kubectl port-forward` (authenticated by Kubernetes kubeconfig). Not exposed to the tailnet.
   466
   467**Single-pod requirement:** PKCE state is in-memory. The gateway runs as a single-replica Deployment. Multi-pod is not supported for the admin API flow (init-oauth on pod A, complete-oauth on pod B would fail). This is acceptable  account management is a rare admin operation, not a hot path.
   468
   469### Endpoints
   470
   471| Method | Path | Description |
   472|--------|------|-------------|
   473| `GET` | `/admin/accounts` | List accounts with status |
   474| `POST` | `/admin/accounts/init-oauth` | Start OAuth PKCE flow, returns authorization URL |
   475| `POST` | `/admin/accounts/complete-oauth` | Complete OAuth flow with authorization code |
   476| `DELETE` | `/admin/accounts/{id}` | Remove account from pool |
   477| `GET` | `/admin/pool` | Pool status summary |
   478
   479### Account ID Generation
   480
   481New accounts are assigned IDs in the format `claude-max-{unix_timestamp}` (e.g., `claude-max-1739059200`). Must be unique within the credential file.
   482
   483### PKCE State Storage
   484
   485Between `init-oauth` and `complete-oauth`, the gateway stores PKCE verifiers in an in-memory `HashMap<String, PkceState>` keyed by account ID. Entries expire after 10 minutes. No persistence needed  if the gateway restarts mid-flow, the admin simply re-initiates.
   486
   487```rust
   488struct PkceState {
   489    verifier: String,
   490    created_at: Instant,
   491}
   492```
   493
   494### Init OAuth Response
   495
   496```json
   497{
   498  "authorization_url": "https://claude.ai/oauth/authorize?client_id=...&code_challenge=...&state=...",
   499  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
   500  "instructions": "Open the URL in a browser, authorize, then paste the code to complete-oauth"
   501}
   502```
   503
   504### Complete OAuth Request
   505
   506```json
   507{
   508  "account_id": "claude-max-1739059200",
   509  "code": "{authorization_code}#{state}"
   510}
   511```
   512
   513---
   514
   515## Health Endpoint (Upgraded)
   516
   517The existing `/health` endpoint expands to include pool status:
   518
   519### Passthrough Mode (backward compatible)
   520
   521```json
   522{
   523  "status": "healthy",
   524  "mode": "passthrough",
   525  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   526  "requests_served": 12345,
   527  "errors_total": 0
   528}
   529```
   530
   531### OAuth Pool Mode
   532
   533```json
   534{
   535  "status": "healthy",
   536  "mode": "oauth_pool",
   537  "uptime_seconds": 3600,
   538  "requests_served": 12345,
   539  "errors_total": 0,
   540  "pool": {
   541    "accounts_total": 3,
   542    "accounts_available": 2,
   543    "accounts_cooling": 1,
   544    "accounts_disabled": 0,
   545    "accounts": [
   546      { "id": "claude-max-1", "status": "available" },
   547      { "id": "claude-max-2", "status": "cooling_down", "cooldown_remaining_secs": 3600 },
   548      { "id": "claude-max-3", "status": "available" }
   549    ]
   550  }
   551}
   552```
   553
   554### Health Status Mapping
   555
   556| Pool State | Status |
   557|------------|--------|
   558| All available | `healthy` |
   559| 1 available, some cooling/disabled | `degraded` |
   560| All cooling or disabled | `unhealthy` (still returns 200  Kubernetes probes check JSON) |
   561
   562---
   563
   564## Metrics (Extended)
   565
   566Existing metrics are preserved. New metrics for OAuth:
   567
   568| Metric | Type | Labels |
   569|--------|------|--------|
   570| `proxy_requests_total` | Counter | `status`, `method` (existing) |
   571| `proxy_request_duration_seconds` | Histogram | `status` (existing) |
   572| `proxy_upstream_errors_total` | Counter | `error_type` (existing) |
   573| `pool_account_status` | Gauge | `account_id`, `status` |
   574| `pool_failovers_total` | Counter | `from_account`, `reason` |
   575| `pool_token_refreshes_total` | Counter | `account_id`, `result` |
   576| `pool_quota_exhaustions_total` | Counter | `account_id` |
   577
   578---
   579
   580## Project Structure (Target)
   581
   582```text
   583crates/
   584  common/               # Shared types: error types (existing)
   585  provider/             # NEW: Provider trait, ErrorClassification
   586  anthropic-auth/       # NEW: OAuth PKCE, token refresh, credential storage
   587  anthropic-pool/       # NEW: Subscription pool, round-robin, failover
   588services/
   589  oauth-proxy/          # Existing binary, upgraded
   590    src/
   591      main.rs           # Entry point (existing, extended)
   592      config.rs         # Config (existing, extended with [oauth] section)
   593      service.rs        # Service state machine (existing)
   594      proxy.rs          # HTTP proxy (existing, call provider.prepare_request())
   595      metrics.rs        # Metrics (existing, extended)
   596      admin.rs          # NEW: Admin API routes
   597      provider_impl.rs  # NEW: AnthropicProvider implementing Provider trait
   598specs/
   599  oauth-proxy.md              # Original spec (Complete, preserved)
   600  anthropic-oauth-gateway.md  # This spec
   601```
   602
   603### Crate Dependency Graph
   604
   605```text
   606oauth-proxy (binary)
   607   common
   608   provider          (trait definition)
   609   anthropic-auth    (PKCE, token refresh, credentials)
   610   anthropic-pool    (pool state, selection, failover)
   611         anthropic-auth
   612```
   613
   614---
   615
   616## Deployment Changes
   617
   618### PersistentVolumeClaim
   619
   620Credential file must survive pod restarts. Add a PVC mounted at `/data/`:
   621
   622```yaml
   623apiVersion: v1
   624kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
   625metadata:
   626  name: anthropic-oauth-credentials
   627  namespace: tailnet
   628spec:
   629  accessModes: [ReadWriteOnce]
   630  resources:
   631    requests:
   632      storage: 1Mi
   633```
   634
   635### ConfigMap Update
   636
   637Add `[oauth]` section to the existing ConfigMap. Backward compatible  removing the section reverts to passthrough mode.
   638
   639### Service (Admin)
   640
   641Optional second Service on port 9090 for admin API. Not exposed via Ingress. Accessible via `kubectl port-forward` or from within the cluster.
   642
   643### No Other Changes
   644
   645Same Deployment, same Ingress, same MagicDNS hostname, same container image tag pattern. The binary detects its mode from config.
   646
   647---
   648
   649## Implementation Phases
   650
   651### Phase 1: Provider Abstraction + Mode Detection
   652
   653- [x] Create `crates/provider/` with `Provider` trait and `ErrorClassification`
   654- [x] Create `PassthroughProvider` implementing `Provider` trait (wraps current header injection logic)
   655- [x] Extend `config.rs` with `[oauth]` section parsing and mode detection
   656- [x] Refactor `proxy.rs` to call `provider.prepare_request()` instead of inline header injection
   657- [x] Body handling fork: passthrough = opaque bytes, oauth = deserialize (stubbed  passthrough provider uses opaque path)
   658- [x] All existing tests pass, behavior unchanged (passthrough provider reproduces current behavior exactly)
   659
   660### Phase 2: OAuth Foundation
   661
   662- [x] Create `crates/anthropic-auth/` with PKCE generation (verifier + S256 challenge)
   663- [x] Implement token exchange (`authorization_code` grant)
   664- [x] Implement token refresh (`refresh_token` grant)
   665- [x] Implement credential file storage (read/write JSON, 0600 permissions)
   666- [x] Unit tests for PKCE, exchange, refresh, storage
   667
   668### Phase 3: Subscription Pool
   669
   670- [x] Create `crates/anthropic-pool/` with `AccountStatus` state machine
   671- [x] Implement round-robin account selection
   672- [x] Implement quota detection (429 message parsing)
   673- [x] Implement cooldown management
   674- [x] Implement proactive background refresh task
   675- [x] Unit tests for selection, failover, cooldown transitions, quota detection
   676
   677### Phase 4: Gateway Integration
   678
   679- [x] Implement `AnthropicOAuthProvider` using pool + auth crates
   680- [x] Header injection: Bearer token, beta flags, User-Agent, dangerous-direct-browser-access
   681- [x] System prompt prefix injection (body modification for Opus/Sonnet)
   682- [x] Model extraction from request body
   683- [x] Extend config.rs with `[oauth]` section parsing
   684- [x] Mode detection: passthrough vs oauth_pool
   685- [x] Extend health endpoint with pool status
   686- [x] Add pool metrics
   687- [x] Integration tests with mock Anthropic API
   688
   689### Phase 5: Admin API
   690
   691- [x] Implement admin router on separate port
   692- [x] `GET /admin/accounts`  list with pool status
   693- [x] `POST /admin/accounts/init-oauth`  generate PKCE, return authorization URL
   694- [x] `POST /admin/accounts/complete-oauth`  exchange code, store credentials, add to pool
   695- [x] `DELETE /admin/accounts/{id}`  remove from pool, update credential file
   696- [x] `GET /admin/pool`  pool summary
   697
   698### Phase 6: Deployment
   699
   700- [x] Add PVC manifest for credential storage
   701- [x] Update ConfigMap with `[oauth]` section
   702- [x] Optional admin Service manifest
   703- [x] Update RUNBOOK.md with OAuth operational procedures
   704- [x] E2E test: add account  proxy request  verify Claude API response
   705
   706---
   707
   708## Success Criteria
   709
   710- [x] Backward compatible: existing `[[headers]]` config works unchanged
   711- [x] OAuth PKCE flow completes: admin adds account via CLI/API
   712- [x] Token auto-refresh: no manual token management after initial auth
   713- [x] Pool failover: quota exhaustion on account A  automatic switch to account B
   714- [x] System prompt injection: Opus/Sonnet requests get required prefix
   715- [x] Health endpoint: reports pool status (available/cooling/disabled per account)
   716- [x] Credential persistence: pod restart preserves OAuth tokens
   717- [x] Zero client credentials: ForgeFlare/Claude Code send bare requests
   718
   719---
   720
   721## Security Considerations
   722
   7231. **Credential isolation**: Each account's OAuth tokens independently managed
   7242. **No credential exposure**: Admin API and health endpoint show account IDs and status, never tokens
   7253. **File permissions**: Credential file 0600, owned by container user
   7264. **Admin API isolation**: Separate port, not exposed via Tailscale Ingress
   7275. **System prompt prefix**: Required by Anthropic for Opus/Sonnet  gateway handles this transparently
   7286. **PKCE**: All OAuth flows use S256 challenge to prevent code interception
   729
   730---
   731
   732## Out of Scope
   733
   734- **Non-Anthropic providers**  multi-provider trait is designed in, but only Anthropic is implemented
   735- **Web UI for account management**  admin API is CLI/curl-driven. Web UI is a future enhancement.
   736- **Telemetry/session tracking**  Aperture handles this upstream. The gateway is auth-only.
   737- **Rate limiting / access control**  Aperture handles per-user access. The gateway serves all tailnet traffic equally.
   738- **Console OAuth mode**  only Max (claude.ai) authorization is supported. API key creation via OAuth is not needed.
   739
   740---
   741
   742## Header Discovery Maintenance
   743
   744When Anthropic updates Claude CLI, required headers may change. Maintenance procedure:
   745
   7461. Install updated Claude CLI
   7472. Sniff traffic via mitmproxy: `mitmdump --set flow_detail=4 -p 8888`
   7483. Route CLI through proxy: `HTTPS_PROXY=http://127.0.0.1:8888 claude --print "hello"`
   7494. Compare captured headers against constants in `anthropic-auth`
   7505. Update constants, run tests
   751
   752---
   753
   754## References
   755
   756- Loom `specs/claude-subscription-auth.md`  OAuth 2.0 PKCE implementation details
   757- Loom `specs/anthropic-oauth-pool.md`  Subscription pooling architecture
   758- Loom `specs/anthropic-max-pool-management.md`  Admin API patterns
   759- `aperture/aperture.md`  Multi-provider gateway reference architecture
   760- `specs/oauth-proxy.md`  Current implementation (passthrough header injector)
   761- [OAuth 2.0 PKCE RFC 7636](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7636)
   762- [Anthropic MAX Plan Implementation Guide](https://raw.githubusercontent.REDACTED.md)
   763
   764---
   765
   766*Spec-first. Types define contract. State machine is the program.*
   767

1. `specs/anthropic-oauth-gateway.md` - Updated credential storage section with annotated field reference table, realistic token prefixes (sk-ant-oat*, sk-ant-ort*), and documented the fatal parse error when `type` field is missing.

2. `RUNBOOK.md` - Three additions:
   - "Adding an Account (Keychain Extraction)" section documenting how to extract OAuth tokens from a local Claude Code macOS keychain and load them into the gateway pod
   - "End-to-End Test" section documenting the correct HTTPS test path over tailnet via the Tailscale FQDN
   - "Known Issues" section documenting the OAuth consent page "Invalid request format" issue and the credential file missing `type` field CrashLoopBackOff issue

These are all documentation updates. Consider whether they should be one commit or split logically.

input.command:
git add RUNBOOK.md && git commit -m "$(cat <<'EOF'
docs(runbook): add operational procedures and troubleshooting

Add three new sections:
- End-to-End Test: correct HTTPS path over tailnet via FQDN, common failure modes
- Adding an Account (Keychain Extraction): macOS keychain extraction for Claude Code
  credentials when PKCE consent fails, with PVC mounting and restart procedure
- Known Issues: document OAuth consent page "Invalid request format" error and
  credential file missing `type` field causing CrashLoopBackOff

Co-Authored-By: Claude Opus 4.6 <noreply@anthropic.com>
EOF
)"
